section.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in paragraph 1 or 1A of this Schedule or in the said scale, no costs shall be allowed in any case to which the said paragraph 1 or 1A applies unless— (L.N. 152 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a case to which sub-paragraph (b) of paragraph 1 applies, judgment or an order for judgment, as the case may be, is obtained within 28 days after the service of the writ or within such further time as the Court may allow.

section.name: s3
section.content: In every case to which the said scale applies there shall be added to the basic costs set out in the said scale the fee which would have been payable on the issue of a writ for the amount recovered.

section.name: s62A
section.heading: Costs Offer and Payments into Court

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation and application (O. 62A, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: In this Order—

def.name: CostsOffer
def.leadIn: costs offer (訟費提議) means an offer to settle—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a party’s entitlement to costs that are the subject of a taxation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs of the taxation;

subsection.def: receiving party (收取方), in relation to a paying party, means the party who is entitled to payment of costs from that paying party;

def.name: RelevantDate
def.leadIn: relevant date (有關日期), in relation to a taxation, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date on which the bill of costs is taxed under Order 62, rule 21B(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date set down under Order 62, rule 21C(1) for hearing the taxation;

subsection.def: sanctioned offer (附帶條款和解提議) means a costs offer made (otherwise than by way of a payment into court) in accordance with this Order;
sanctioned payment (附帶條款付款) means a costs offer made by way of a payment into court in accordance with this Order;
sanctioned payment notice (附帶條款付款通知書) means the notice relating to a sanctioned payment required to be filed under rule 8(2).

subsection.content: This Order does not apply to or in relation to a party who is or has been an aided person in the relevant proceedings.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Offer to settle with specified consequences (O. 62A, r. 2)

subsection.content: Any party to a taxation may make a costs offer in accordance with this Order.
An offer made under paragraph (1) has the consequences specified in rules 18, 19 and 20 (as may be applicable).

Nothing in this Order prevents a party from making a costs offer in whatever way he chooses, but if that costs offer is not made in accordance with this Order, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order, unless the Court so orders.

section.crossHeading: II. Manner of Making Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s3
section.heading: Paying party’s costs offer requires sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 3)

subsection.content: A costs offer by a paying party does not have the consequences specified in this Order unless it is made by way of a sanctioned payment.
A sanctioned payment may be made at any time before the relevant date.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Receiving party’s costs offer requires sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 4)
section.content: A costs offer by a receiving party does not have the consequences specified in this Order unless it is made by way of a sanctioned offer.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Form and content of sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 5)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer must be in writing.
A sanctioned offer may relate to the whole or part of the costs.
A sanctioned offer must state whether it relates to the whole or part of the costs, and if it relates to part of the costs, to which part does it relate.
A sanctioned offer may be made at any time before the relevant date.

subsection.leadIn: A sanctioned offer must provide that after the expiry of 14 days from the date the sanctioned offer is made, the offeree may only accept it if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the parties agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court grants leave to accept it.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Service of sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 6)
section.content: A receiving party who makes a sanctioned offer shall serve the sanctioned offer on the paying party.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Withdrawal or diminution of sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 7)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer may not be withdrawn or diminished before the expiry of 14 days from the date the sanctioned offer is made unless the Court grants leave to withdraw or diminish it.
If there is subsisting an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned offer, the sanctioned offer may not be accepted unless the Court grants leave to accept it.

If the Court dismisses an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned offer or grants leave to diminish the sanctioned offer, it may by order specify the period within which the sanctioned offer or diminished sanctioned offer may be accepted.
If a sanctioned offer is withdrawn, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Notice of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 8)

subsection.content: A sanctioned payment may relate to the whole or part of the costs.

subsection.leadIn: A paying party who makes a sanctioned payment shall file with the Court a notice in Form No. 93 in Appendix A, that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: states the amount of the payment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states whether the payment relates to the whole or part of the costs, and if it relates to part of the costs, to which part it relates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if an interim payment of costs has been made, states that the paying party has taken into account the interim payment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if it is expressed not to be inclusive of interest, states—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether interest is offered; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if so, the amount offered, the rate or rates offered and the period or periods for which it is offered; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if a sum of money has been paid into court as security for the costs of the action, cause or matter, states whether the sanctioned payment has taken into account that sum of money.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Service of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 9)
section.leadIn: A paying party who makes a sanctioned payment shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: serve the sanctioned payment notice on the receiving party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: file with the Court a certificate of service of the notice.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Withdrawal or diminution of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 10)

subsection.content: A sanctioned payment may not be withdrawn or diminished before the expiry of 14 days from the date the sanctioned payment is made unless the Court grants leave to withdraw or diminish it.
If there is subsisting an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned payment, the sanctioned payment may not be accepted unless the Court grants leave to accept it.

If the Court dismisses an application to withdraw or diminish a sanctioned payment or grants leave to diminish the sanctioned payment, it may by order specify the period within which the sanctioned payment or diminished sanctioned payment may be accepted.
If a sanctioned payment is withdrawn, it does not have the consequences specified in this Order.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Time when sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is made and accepted (O. 62A, r. 11)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer is made when it is served on the offeree.
A sanctioned payment is made when a sanctioned payment notice is served on the offeree.
An amendment to a sanctioned offer is effective when its details are served on the offeree.
An amendment to a sanctioned payment is effective when notice of the amendment is served on the offeree.
A sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment is accepted when notice of its acceptance is served on the offeror.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Clarification of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment notice (O. 62A, r. 12)

subsection.content: The offeree may, within 7 days of a sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment being made, request the offeror to clarify the offer or payment notice.
If the offeror does not give the clarification requested under paragraph (1) within 7 days of service of the request, the offeree may, before the relevant date, apply for an order that he does so.
If the Court makes an order pursuant to an application made under paragraph (2), it shall specify the date when the sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment is to be treated as having been made.

section.crossHeading: III. Acceptance of Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s13
section.heading: Time for acceptance of paying party’s sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 13)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 10(2) and paragraph (2), a receiving party may accept a sanctioned payment at any time before the relevant date without requiring the leave of the Court if he files with the Court and serves on the paying party a written notice of acceptance not later than 14 days after the payment was made.

subsection.leadIn: If the receiving party does not accept a paying party’s sanctioned payment within the 14-day period specified in paragraph (1), then the receiving party may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the parties agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, accept the payment without the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the parties do not agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, only accept the payment with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Where the leave of the Court is required under paragraph (2), the Court shall, if it grants leave, make an order as to costs.
A notice of acceptance of a sanctioned payment must be in Form No. 93A in Appendix A.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Time for acceptance of receiving party’s sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 14)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 7(2) and paragraph (2), a paying party may accept a sanctioned offer at any time before the relevant date without requiring the leave of the Court if he files with the Court and serves on the receiving party a written notice of acceptance not later than 14 days after the offer was made.

subsection.leadIn: If the paying party does not accept a receiving party’s sanctioned offer within the 14-day period specified in paragraph (1), then the paying party may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the parties agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, accept the offer without the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the parties do not agree on the liability for and quantum of costs of taxation incurred after the expiry of the period, only accept the offer with the leave of the Court.

subsection.content: Where the leave of the Court is required under paragraph (2), the Court shall, if it grants leave, make an order as to costs.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Payment out of a sum in court on acceptance of sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 15)
section.content: Subject to rule 16(4), where a sanctioned payment is accepted, the receiving party may obtain payment out of the sum in court by making a request for payment in Form No. 93B in Appendix A.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Acceptance of sanctioned payment made by one or more, but not all, paying parties (O. 62A, r. 16)

subsection.content: This rule applies where the receiving party wishes to accept a sanctioned payment made by one or more, but not all, of a number of paying parties.

subsection.leadIn: If the paying parties are jointly and severally liable to pay costs, the receiving party may accept the payment in accordance with rule 13 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he discontinues the proceedings for taxation against those paying parties who have not made the payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those paying parties give written consent to the acceptance of the payment.

subsection.leadIn: If the paying parties are not jointly, but severally liable to pay costs, the receiving party may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: accept the payment in accordance with rule 13; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: continue with his proceedings for taxation against the other paying parties.

subsection.leadIn: In all other cases the receiving party shall apply to the Court for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order permitting a payment out to him of any sum in court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such order as to costs relating to the taxation as the Court considers appropriate.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Cases where court order is required to enable acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 17)
section.leadIn: Where a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment is made in proceedings to which Order 80, rule 10 (Compromise, etc., by person under disability) applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offer or payment may be accepted only with the leave of the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no payment out of any sum in court may be made without a court order.

section.crossHeading: IV. Consequences of Sanctioned Offer or Sanctioned Payment

section.name: s18
section.heading: Consequences of acceptance of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 18)

subsection.content: If a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment relates to the whole costs and is accepted, the taxation is stayed.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of acceptance of a sanctioned offer which relates to the whole costs—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the stay is upon the terms of the offer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: either party may apply to enforce those terms without the need to commence new proceedings.

subsection.content: If a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment which relates to part only of the costs is accepted, the taxation is stayed as to that part.

If the approval of the Court is required before a settlement as to costs can be binding, any stay which would otherwise arise on the acceptance of a sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment takes effect only when that approval has been given.

subsection.leadIn: Any stay arising under this rule does not affect the power of the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enforce the terms of a sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to deal with any question of costs (including interest on costs) relating to the taxation; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to order payment out of court of any sum paid into court.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sanctioned offer has been accepted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a party alleges that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the other party has not honoured the terms of the offer; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is therefore entitled to a remedy for breach of contract,

subsection.continued: the party may claim the remedy by applying to the Court without the need to commence new proceedings unless the Court orders otherwise.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Costs consequences where receiving party fails to better sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 19)

subsection.content: This rule applies where upon taxation a receiving party fails to better a sanctioned payment.

The taxing master may by order disallow all or part of any interest otherwise payable under section 49 of the Ordinance on the whole or part of the amount of the costs awarded to the receiving party for some or all of the period after the latest date on which the payment could have been accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: The taxing master may also—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the receiving party to pay the costs of the taxation on the indemnity basis after the date on which the payment was made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order that the paying party is entitled to interest on those costs at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate.

subsection.content: Where this rule applies, the taxing master shall make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3) unless he considers it unjust to do so.

subsection.leadIn: In considering whether it would be unjust to make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3), the taxing master shall take into account all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of the sanctioned payment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the stage in the proceedings at which the sanctioned payment was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information available to the parties at the time when the sanctioned payment was made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the conduct of the parties with regard to the giving or refusing to give information for the purposes of enabling the payment to be made or evaluated.

subsection.content: The power of the taxing master under this rule is in addition to any other power he may have to award or disallow interest.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Costs and other consequences where receiving party does better than he proposed in his sanctioned offer (O. 62A, r. 20)

subsection.content: This rule applies where upon taxation a paying party is held liable for more than the proposals contained in a receiving party’s sanctioned offer.

The taxing master may order interest on the whole or part of the amount of the costs allowed to the receiving party at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate for some or all of the period after the date on which the sanctioned offer was served on the paying party.

subsection.leadIn: The taxing master may also order that the receiving party is entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his costs on the indemnity basis after the date on which the sanctioned offer was served on the paying party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: interest on those costs at a rate not exceeding 10% above judgment rate.

subsection.content: Where this rule applies, the taxing master shall make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3) unless he considers it unjust to do so.

subsection.leadIn: In considering whether it would be unjust to make the orders referred to in paragraphs (2) and (3), the taxing master shall take into account all the circumstances of the case including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the terms of the sanctioned offer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the stage in the proceedings at which the sanctioned offer was made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information available to the parties at the time when the sanctioned offer was made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the conduct of the parties with regard to the giving or refusing to give information for the purposes of enabling the offer to be made or evaluated.

subsection.content: The power of the taxing master under this rule is in addition to any other power he may have to award interest.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Restriction on disclosure of sanctioned offer or sanctioned payment (O. 62A, r. 21)

subsection.content: A sanctioned offer is treated as “without prejudice save as to costs”.
The fact that a sanctioned payment has been made must not be communicated to the taxing master until the amount of the costs to be allowed have been decided.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraph (2) does not apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the taxation has been stayed under rule 18 following acceptance of a sanctioned payment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the fact that there has or has not been a sanctioned payment may be relevant to the question of the costs of the issue of liability.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Interest (O. 62A, r. 22)

subsection.leadIn: Unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a receiving party’s sanctioned offer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a sanctioned payment notice,

subsection.continued: indicates to the contrary, any such offer or payment is to be treated as inclusive of all interest until the last date on which it could be accepted without requiring the leave of the Court.

subsection.leadIn: Where a receiving party’s sanctioned offer or a sanctioned payment notice is expressed not to be inclusive of interest, the offer or notice must state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether interest is offered; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so, the amount offered, the rate or rates offered and the period or periods for which it is offered.

section.name: s63
section.heading: The Registry

section.name: s2
section.heading: Practice master (O. 63, r. 2)
section.content: Subject to the direction of the Registrar one of the masters shall be present at the Registry on every day on which the Registry is open for the purpose of superintending the business performed there and giving any directions which may be required on questions of practice and procedure.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Date of filing to be marked, etc. (O. 63, r. 3)

subsection.content: Any document filed in the Registry in any proceedings must be marked showing the date on which the document was filed.

Particulars of the time of delivery at the Registry of any document for filing, the date of the document and the title of the cause or matter of which the document forms part of the record shall be entered in books kept in the Registry for the purpose.

section.name: s3A
section.heading: Filing of documents in the Registry (O. 63, r. 3A)

subsection.content: Subject to paragraph (2) and to Order 12, rule 1(3), any document to be filed in court in accordance with these rules or by order of the Court shall be filed by delivering such document to the Registry by hand.

When any document is to be filed by a litigant in person, not being a director representing a body corporate by leave of the Court given pursuant to Order 5, rule 6(3) or Order 12, rule 1(2A), such document may be filed by sending it by post to the Registry, and the date of filing thereof shall be the date the document is received by the Registry.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Right to inspect, etc. certain documents filed in the Registry (O. 63, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Any person shall, on payment of the prescribed fee, be entitled during such hours as the Registrar may direct to search for, inspect and obtain a copy of any of the following documents filed in the Registry, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the copy of any writ of summons or other originating process,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any judgment or order given or made in court or the copy of any such judgment or order, and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: with the leave of the Court, which may be granted on an application made ex parte, any other document.

subsection.content: Nothing in the foregoing provisions shall be taken as preventing any party to a cause or matter searching for, inspecting and obtaining a copy of any affidavit or other document filed in the Registry in that cause or matter or filed therein before the commencement of that cause or matter but made with a view to its commencement.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Deposit of documents (O. 63, r. 5)
section.content: Where the Court orders any documents to be lodged in court, they must, unless otherwise directed, be deposited in the Registry.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Inspection, etc. of powers of attorney (O. 63, r. 8)

subsection.content: An index shall be kept in the Registry of all powers of attorney which have been deposited in the Registry prior to 1 October 1972.

subsection.leadIn: Any person shall, on payment of the prescribed fee, be entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: search the index;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inspect any power of attorney and any document which has been deposited together with the power of attorney; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: office copies of the power of attorney and any document relating thereto,

subsection.continued: and a copy of such power of attorney and document may be presented at the Registry to be marked as office copies.

subsection.leadIn: Any person shall, on payment of the prescribed fee, be entitled to—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: inspect any enduring power of attorney lodged under section 9(3) of that Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: office copies of the enduring power of attorney,

subsection.continued: and a copy of such enduring power of attorney may be presented at the Registry to be marked as an office copy. (L.N. 284 of 1997)

section.name: s9
section.heading: Restriction on removal of documents (O. 63, r. 9)
section.content: No document filed in or in the custody of the Registry of the High Court shall be taken out of that Registry without the leave of the Court.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Enrolment of instruments (O. 63, r. 10)
section.leadIn: Any deed which by virtue of any written law is required or authorized to be enrolled in the High Court may be enrolled in the Registry.
section.continued: In this rule deed (契據) includes assurances and other instruments.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Sittings, Vacations and Office Hours

section.name: s1
section.heading: Sittings of the Supreme Court (O. 64, r. 1)

subsection.leadIn: The sittings of the Court of Appeal and of the Court of First Instance shall be three in every year, that is to say— (25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Winter sittings which shall begin on 4 January and end on the Thursday before Easter Sunday;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Spring sittings which shall begin on the second Monday after Easter Sunday and end on 31 July;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Autumn sittings which shall begin on 1 September and end on 23 December. (L.N. 404 of 1991)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Court of Appeal (O. 64, r. 2)

subsection.content: The Court of Appeal shall sit in vacation on such days as the Chief Justice may, from time to time direct to hear such appeals or applications as require to be immediately or promptly heard and to hear other appeals and applications if the Chief Justice determines that sittings are necessary for that purpose.

Any party to an appeal may at any time apply to the Court of Appeal for an order that the appeal be heard in vacation and, if that Court is satisfied that the appeal requires to be immediately or promptly heard, it may make an order accordingly and fix a date for the hearing.
The Court of Appeal may hear such other appeals in vacation as that Court may direct.
The provisions of O. 59, r. 10(9) shall apply to the powers conferred on the Court of Appeal by this rule.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Court of First Instance (O. 64, r. 3)

subsection.content: One or more judges of the Court of First Instance shall sit in vacation on such days as the Chief Justice may, from time to time direct, to hear such causes, matters or applications as require to be immediately or promptly heard and to hear other causes, matters or applications if the Chief Justice determines that sittings are necessary for that purpose.

Any party to a cause or matter may at any time apply to the Court for an order that such cause or matter be heard in vacation and, if the Court is satisfied that the cause or matter requires to be immediately or promptly heard, it may make an order accordingly and fix a date for the hearing.
Any judge of the Court of First Instance may hear such other causes or matters in vacation as the Court may direct.

section.name: s3A
section.heading: Business in vacation (O. 64, r. 3A)

subsection.leadIn: Upon application by any party to an action or matter, the Court may, if it thinks fit— (L.N. 122 of 2017)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complete such action or matter in vacation if it is partheard; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deliver judgment in such action or matter in vacation.

section.name: s7
section.heading: High Court Offices: days on which open and office hours (O. 64, r. 7)

subsection.leadIn: The offices of the High Court shall be open on every day of the year except Saturdays and general holidays.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: However, the Registrar or the Chief Justice may from time to time direct an office of the High Court to be open or closed on any day. (18 of 2016 s. 7)
The hours during which any office of the High Court shall be open to the public shall be such as the Registrar or the Chief Justice may from time to time direct.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Service of Documents

section.name: s1
section.heading: When personal service required (O. 65, r. 1)

subsection.content: Any document which by virtue of these rules is required to be served on any person need not be served personally unless the document is one which by an express provision of these rules or by order of the Court is required to be so served.
Paragraph (1) shall not affect the power of the Court under any provision of these rules to dispense with the requirement for personal service.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Personal service: how effected (O. 65, r. 2)
section.content: Personal service of a document is effected by leaving a copy of the document with the person to be served.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Personal service on body corporate (O. 65, r. 3)

subsection.content: Personal service of a document on a body corporate may, in cases for which provision is not otherwise made by any written law, be effected by serving it in accordance with rule 2 on the chairman or president of the body, or the clerk, secretary, treasurer or other similar officer thereof.

Where a writ is served on a body corporate in accordance with Order 10, rule 1(2), that rule shall have effect as if for the reference to the usual or last known address of the defendant there were substituted a reference to the registered or principal office of the body corporate and as if for the reference to the knowledge of the defendant there were substituted a reference to the knowledge of a person mentioned in paragraph (1).

section.name: s4
section.heading: Substituted service (O. 65, r. 4)

subsection.content: If, in the case of any document which by virtue of any provision of these rules is required to be served personally or in the case of a document to which Order 10, rule 1, applies, it appears to the Court that it is impracticable for any reason to serve that document in the manner prescribed on that person, the Court may make an order for substituted service of that document.
An application for an order for substituted service may be made by an affidavit stating the facts on which the application is founded.

Substituted service of a document, in relation to which an order is made under this rule, is effected by taking such steps as the Court may direct to bring the document to the notice of the person to be served.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Ordinary service: how effected (O. 65, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Service of any document, not being a document which by virtue of any provision of these rules is required to be served personally or a document to which Order 10, rule 1, applies, may be effected—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by leaving the document at the proper address of the person to be served, or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by post, or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the proper address for service includes a numbered box at a document exchange, by leaving the document at that document exchange or at a document exchange which transmits documents every business day to that document exchange, or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: in such other manner as the court may direct.

subsection.continued: In these rules document exchange (文件轉遞處) means any document exchange, or exchanges under the control of the same operator, for the time being approved by the Chief Justice. (L.N. 223 of 1995)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this rule, and of section 8 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1), in its application to this rule, the proper address of any person on whom a document is to be served in accordance with this rule shall be the address for service of that person, but if at the time when service is effected that person has no address for service his proper address for the purposes aforesaid shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in any case, the business address of the solicitor (if any) who is acting for him in the proceedings in connection with which service of the document in question is to be effected, or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an individual, his usual or last known address, or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of individuals who are suing or being sued in the name of a firm, the principal or last known place of business of the firm within the jurisdiction, or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of a body corporate, the registered or principal office of the body.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Any such document which is left at a document exchange in accordance with paragraph (1)(c) shall, unless the contrary is proved, be deemed to have been served on the business day following the day on which it is left.

Nothing in this rule shall be taken as prohibiting the personal service of any document or as affecting any enactment which provides for the manner in which documents may be served on bodies corporate.

subsection.def: In this rule business day (工作天) means a day other than a general holiday.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Service on Secretary for Justice in proceedings which are not by or against the Crown (O. 65, r. 6)
section.content: Where for the purpose of or in connection with any proceedings in the High Court, not being civil proceedings by or against the Crown within the meaning of Part III of the Crown Proceedings Ordinance (Cap. 300), any document is required by any written law or these rules to be served on the Secretary for Justice, section 14 of the said Ordinance and Order 77, rule 4, shall apply in relation to the service of the document as they apply in relation to the service of documents required to be served on the Crown for the purpose of or in connection with any civil proceedings by or against the Crown.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Effect of service at certain time (O. 65, r. 7)

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if a document (other than a writ of summons or other originating process) is served under rule 2 or 5(1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on a specified day; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after 4 p.m. on another day.

subsection.content: For computing a period of time after service of the document, the document is deemed to be served on the next following day, not being a specified day.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: specified day (指明日子) means—(a)a Saturday;(b)a general holiday;(c)a gale warning day as defined by section 71(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1); or(d)a black rainstorm warning day as defined by that section.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Affidavit of service (O. 65, r. 8)
section.content: Except as provided in Order 10, rule 1(3)(b) and Order 81, rule 3(2)(b), an affidavit of service of any document must state by whom the document was served, the day of the week and date on which it was served, where it was served and how.

section.name: s9
section.heading: No service required in certain cases (O. 65, r. 9)
section.content: Where by virtue of these rules any document is required to be served on any person but it is not required to be served personally or in accordance with Order 10, rule 1(2), and at the time when service is to be effected that person is in default as to acknowledgment of service or has no address for service, the document need not be served on that person unless the Court otherwise directs or any of these rules otherwise provides.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Service of process on Sunday (O. 65, r. 10)

subsection.content: No process shall be served or executed within the jurisdiction on a Sunday, except, in case of urgency, with the leave of the Court.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Paragraph (1) does not apply in relation to the service of any process under the Court Proceedings (Electronic Technology) (High Court Civil Proceedings) Rules. (L.N. 60 of 2025)

subsection.def: For the purposes of this rule process (法律程序文件) includes a writ, judgment, notice, order, petition, originating or other summons or warrant.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Paper, Printing, Notices and Copies

section.name: s1
section.heading: Quality of paper (O. 66, r. 1)
section.content: Unless the nature of the document renders it impracticable, every document prepared by a party for use in the Court must be on paper of durable quality, having a margin not less than 35 mm wide, to be left blank on the left side of the face of the paper and on the right side of the reverse.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Regulations as to printing, etc. (O. 66, r. 2)

subsection.content: Except where these rules otherwise provide, every document prepared by a party for use in the High Court must be produced by one of the following means, that is to say, printing, writing (which must be clear and legible) and typewriting otherwise than by means of a carbon, and may be produced partly by one of those means and partly by another or others of them. (25 of 1998 s. 2)
For the purposes of these rules a document shall be deemed to be printed if it is produced by type lithography or stencil duplicating.

Any type used in producing a document for use as aforesaid must be such as to give a clear and legible impression and must be not smaller than 11 point type for printing or elite type for type lithography, stencil duplicating or typewriting.

Any document produced by a photographic or similar process giving a positive and permanent representation free from blemishes shall, to the extent that it contains a facsimile of any printed, written or typewritten matter, be treated for the purposes of these rules as if it were printed, written or typewritten, as the case may be.
Any notice required by these rules may not be given orally except with the leave of the Court.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Copies of documents for other party (O. 66, r. 3)

subsection.content: Where a document prepared by a party for use in the High Court is printed the party by whom it was prepared must, on receiving a written request from any other party entitled to a copy of that document and on payment of the proper charges, supply him with such number of copies thereof, not exceeding ten, as may be specified in the request.

subsection.leadIn: Where a document prepared by a party for use in the High Court is written or typewritten, the party by whom it was prepared must supply any other party entitled to a copy of it, not being a party on whom it has been served, with one copy of it and, where the document in question is an affidavit, of any document exhibited to it.
subsection.continued: The copy must be ready for delivery within 48 hours after a written request for it, together with an undertaking to pay the proper charges, is received and must be supplied thereafter on payment of those charges.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Requirements as to copies (O. 66, r. 4)

subsection.content: Before a copy of a document is supplied to a party under these rules, it must be indorsed with the name and address of the party or solicitor by whom it was supplied.

The party by whom a copy is supplied under rule 3, or, if he sues or appears by a solicitor, his solicitor, shall be answerable for the copy being a true copy of the original or of an office copy, as the case may be.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Change of Solicitor

section.name: s1
section.heading: Notice of change of solicitor (O. 67, r. 1)

subsection.content: A party to any cause or matter who sues or defends by a solicitor may change his solicitor without an order for that purpose but, unless and until notice of the change is filed and copies of the notice are lodged and served in accordance with this rule, the former solicitor shall, subject to rules 5 and 6, be considered the solicitor of the party until the final conclusion of the cause or matter, whether in the Court of First Instance or the Court of Appeal. (25 of 1998 s. 2)
Notice of a change of solicitor must be filed, and a copy thereof lodged in the Registry.

The party giving the notice must serve on every other party to the cause or matter (not being a party in default as to acknowledgment of service) and on the former solicitor a copy of the notice indorsed with a memorandum stating that the notice has been duly filed in the Registry.
The party giving the notice may perform the duties prescribed by this rule in person or by his new solicitor.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Notice of appointment of solicitor (O. 67, r. 3)
section.content: Where a party, after having sued or defended in person, appoints a solicitor to act in the cause or matter on his behalf, the change may be made without an order for that purpose and rule 1(2), (3) and (4) shall, with the necessary modifications, apply in relation to a notice of appointment of a solicitor as they apply in relation to a notice of change of solicitor.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Notice of intention to act in person (O. 67, r. 4)
section.content: Where a party, after having sued or defended by a solicitor, intends and is entitled to act in person, the change may be made without an order for that purpose and rule 1 shall, with the necessary modifications, apply in relation to a notice of intention to act in person as it applies in relation to a notice of change of solicitor except that the notice of intention to act in person must contain an address for service of the party giving it.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Removal of solicitor from record at instance of another party (O. 67, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a solicitor who has acted for a party in a cause or matter has died or become bankrupt or cannot be found or has failed to take out a practising certificate or has been struck off the roll of solicitors or has been suspended from practising or has for any other reason ceased to practise, and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the party has not given notice of change of solicitor or notice of intention to act in person in accordance with the foregoing provisions of this Order,

subsection.continued: any other party to the cause or matter may apply to the Court, or if an appeal to the Court of Appeal is pending in the cause or matter, to the Court of Appeal, for an order declaring that the solicitor has ceased to be the solicitor acting for the first-mentioned party in the cause or matter, and the Court or Court of Appeal, as the case may be, may make an order accordingly.

subsection.content:
An application for an order under this rule must be made by summons and the summons must, unless the Court or Court of Appeal, as the case may be, otherwise directs, be served on the party to whose solicitor the application relates. (L.N. 152 of 2008)
The application must be supported by an affidavit stating the grounds of the application.

subsection.leadIn: Where an order is made under this rule the party on whose application it was made must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: serve on every other party to the cause or matter (not being a party in default as to acknowledgment of service) a copy of the order, and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: procure the order to be entered in the Registry, and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: leave at the Registry a copy of the order and a certificate signed by him or his solicitor that the order has been duly served as aforesaid.

subsection.content: An order made under this rule shall not affect the rights of the solicitor and the party for whom he acted as between themselves.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Withdrawal of solicitor who has ceased to act for party (O. 67, r. 6)

subsection.leadIn: Where a solicitor who has acted for a party in a cause or matter has ceased so to act and the party has not given notice of change in accordance with rule 1, or notice of intention to act in person in accordance with rule 4, the solicitor may apply to the Court for an order declaring that the solicitor has ceased to be the solicitor acting for the party in the cause or matter, and the Court or Court of Appeal, as the case may be, may make an order accordingly, but, unless and until the solicitor—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: serves on every party to the cause or matter (not being a party in default as to acknowledgment of service) a copy of the order, and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: procures the order to be entered in the Registry, and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: leaves at the Registry a copy of the order and a certificate signed by him that the order has been duly served as aforesaid,

subsection.continued: he shall, subject to the foregoing provisions of this Order, be considered the solicitor of the party till the final conclusion of the cause or matter whether in the Court of First Instance or Court of Appeal. (25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: An application for an order under this rule must be made by summons which must, unless the Court or the Court of Appeal, as the case may be, otherwise directs, be served on the party for whom the solicitor acted. The application must be supported by an affidavit stating the grounds of the application. (L.N. 363 of 1990)
An order made under this rule shall not affect the rights of the solicitor and the party for whom he acted as between themselves.

Notwithstanding anything in paragraph (1), where the certificate of an assisted person within the meaning of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) is revoked or discharged, the solicitor who acted for the assisted person shall cease to be the solicitor acting in the cause or matter as soon as his retainer is determined under that Ordinance; and if the assisted person whose certificate has been revoked or discharged desires to proceed with the cause or matter without legal aid and appoints that solicitor or another solicitor to act on his behalf, the provisions of rule 3 shall apply as if that party had previously sued or defended in person.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Leave required to inspect affidavits (O. 67, r. 6A)
section.content: Notwithstanding the provisions of Order 63, rule 4(2), the leave of the Court or the Court of Appeal, as the case may be, is required before inspection can be made, or any copy obtained, of any affidavit made or filed pursuant to rule 6(2).

section.name: s7
section.heading: Address for service of party whose solicitor is removed, etc. (O. 67, r. 7)
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order is made under rule 5, or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order is made under rule 6, and the applicant for that order has complied with rule 6(1), or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the certificate of an assisted person within the meaning of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) is revoked or discharged,

section.continued: then, unless and until the party to whose solicitor or to whom, as the case may be, the order or certificate relates either appoints another solicitor and complies with rule 3 or, being entitled to act in person, gives notice of his intention so to do and complies with rule 4, his last known address or, where the party is a body corporate, its registered or principal office shall, for the purpose of the service on him of any document not required to be served personally, be deemed to be his address for service.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Order to apply to matrimonial causes and matters (O. 67, r. 9)
section.content: This Order shall have effect in relation to matrimonial causes and matters and, in its application to such a cause or matter, any reference in rules 4 and 7 to an address for service shall be construed as a reference to the address for service required by the rules in force by virtue of the provisions of section 10 or made under section 54 of the Matrimonial Causes Ordinance (Cap. 179).

section.name: s68
section.heading: Official Shorthand Note

section.name: s1
section.heading: Official shorthand note of all evidence, etc.(O. 68, r. 1)

subsection.content: In every action or other proceeding in the Court of First Instance which is tried or heard with witnesses, an official shorthand note shall, unless the judge otherwise directs, be taken of any evidence given orally in court and of any summing up by the judge and of any judgment delivered by him, and, if any party so requires the note so taken shall be transcribed and such number of transcripts as any party may demand shall be supplied to him at the charges authorized by any scheme in force providing for the taking of official shorthand notes of proceedings in the Court of First Instance. (25 of 1998 s. 2)
Nothing in this rule shall be construed as prohibiting the supply of transcripts to persons not parties to the proceedings.
The powers of the Court of Appeal under this Order may be exercised by a single judge of that Court or by the registrar of civil appeals.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Evidence when not to be transcribed (O. 68, r. 2)

subsection.content: If the judge intimates that in the event of an appeal his note will be sufficient, the shorthand note of the evidence need not be transcribed for the purposes of an appeal.

If the parties agree or the judge is of opinion that the evidence or some part of the evidence of any witness would, in the event of an appeal, be of no assistance to the Court of Appeal, the shorthand note of such evidence need not be transcribed for the purposes of an appeal.
If any party requires a transcript of any such evidence as aforesaid the charge therefor shall be borne by that party in any event.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Payment for transcripts out of public funds: excepted proceedings (O. 68, r. 3)
section.content: Rules 4 and 5 shall not apply in relation to a transcript of a note taken in proceedings in connection with which legal aid might have been given under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) whether or not such aid was given thereunder to any party to the proceedings.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Payment for transcripts for the Court of Appeal (O. 68, r. 4)

subsection.content: An appellant shall not be required to pay for the transcript to which a certificate given under this rule relates but, except as aforesaid, any transcript required for the Court of Appeal shall be paid for by the appellant in the first instance.

Where the judge by whom any such proceeding as is referred to in rule 1 was tried or heard or the Court of Appeal is satisfied that an appellant in that proceeding is in such poor financial circumstances that the cost of a transcript would be an excessive burden on him, and, in the case of a transcript of evidence, that there is reasonable ground for the appeal, the judge or the Court of Appeal, as the case may be, may certify that the case is one in which it is proper that the said cost should be borne by public funds.

An application for a certificate under this rule must be made in the first instance to the judge; if the application is refused, the application (if any) to the Court of Appeal must be made within 7 days after the refusal.

Where an application is made to the Court of Appeal for a certificate under this rule, then, if the Court of Appeal is of opinion that for the purpose of determining the application it is necessary for that Court to see a transcript of the summing up and judgment, with or without a transcript of the evidence, the Court of Appeal may certify that both transcripts or, as the case may be, only a transcript of the summing up and judgment may properly be supplied for the use of that Court at the expense of public funds.
No transcript supplied for the use of the Court of Appeal under a certificate given under paragraph (4) shall be handed to the appellant except by direction of the Court of Appeal.

Where the judge or the Court of Appeal certifies under paragraph (2) that there is reasonable ground for the appeal, the appellant may be supplied with as many free copies of the transcript referred to in the certificate as will, together with any free copies already supplied under a certificate given under paragraph (4), make up a total of one for his own use and three for the use of the Court of Appeal.
References in this rule to an appellant include references to an intending appellant.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Payment for transcript for poor respondent (O. 68, r. 5)

subsection.content: Where the judge by whom any such proceeding as is referred to in rule 1 was tried or heard or the Court of Appeal is satisfied that the respondent to an appeal in that proceeding is in such poor financial circumstances that the cost of obtaining a transcript, or a specified part thereof, for the purpose of resisting the appeal would be an excessive burden on him, the judge or the Court of Appeal, as the case may be, may certify that the case is one in which it is proper that the cost of the transcript or that part thereof, as the case may be, should be borne by public funds, and where such a certificate is given the respondent shall not be required to pay the said cost.
Rule 4(3) shall apply in relation to an application for a certificate under this rule as it applies in relation to an application for a certificate under that rule.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Mechanical, digital, electronic or optical recording (O. 68, r. 8)
section.content: In this Order any reference to a shorthand note of any proceedings shall be construed as including a reference to a record of the proceedings made by mechanical, digital, electronic or optical means.

section.name: s8A
section.heading: Definition (O. 68, r. 8A)
section.content: In this Order transcript (謄本) includes the transcript of the official shorthand note and any official typescript of the Judge’s manuscript note.

main.crossHeading: Provisions as to Proceedings of a Country or Place Outside Hong Kong

section.name: s69
section.heading: Service of Process from a Country or Place Outside Hong Kong

section.name: s1
section.heading: Definitions (O. 69, r. 1)
section.leadIn: In this Order—
section.def: a convention country (協約國) means a foreign country in relation to which there subsists a civil procedure convention providing for service in that country of process of the Court of First Instance, and includes a country which is a party to the Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extra-Judicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters signed at The Hague on 15 November 1965; (25 of 1998 s. 2)
Mainland (內地) means any part of China other than Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan; (L.N. 25 of 2020)
process (法律程序文件) includes a citation;
process server (法律程序文件送達人) means the process server appointed under rule 4 or his authorized agent;
taxing master (訟費評定官) means a taxing master of the High Court. (25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Applications (O. 69, r. 2)
section.leadIn: This Order applies to the service on a person in Hong Kong of any process related to civil or commercial proceedings in a court or tribunal of a country or place outside Hong Kong if the Registrar receives a written request for service—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: from the Chief Secretary for Administration with a recommendation by the Chief Secretary for Administration that service should be effected;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the court or tribunal is in a convention country—from a consular or other authority of that country;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the court or tribunal is in the Mainland—from the judicial authorities of the Mainland; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the court or tribunal is in Macao—from the judicial authorities of Macao.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Service of process (O. 69, r. 3)

subsection.content: If the request is in a language other than either or both of Hong Kong’s official languages, it shall be accompanied by a translation of the request in either of Hong Kong’s official languages, 2 copies of the process and, unless the court or tribunal of a country or place outside Hong Kong certifies that the person to be served understands the language of the process, 2 copies of the translation of the process. (L.N. 39 of 1999)

Subject to paragraphs (3) and (5) and to any enactment providing for the manner of service of documents on corporate bodies, the process shall be served by the process server’s leaving a copy of the process and a copy of the translation or certificate, as the case may be, with the person to be served.

The provisions of Order 10, rule 1(2)(b) regarding service by insertion through a letter-box shall apply to the service of process from a country or place outside Hong Kong as they apply to the service of writs, except that service may be proved by an affidavit or by a certificate or report in such form as the Registrar may direct. (L.N. 39 of 1999)

The process server shall send to the Registrar a copy of the process and an affidavit, certificate or report proving due service of process or stating the reason why service could not be effected, as the case may be, and shall, if the Court so directs, specify the costs incurred in effecting or attempting to effect service.

Order 65, rule 4 (substituted service) shall apply to the service of process from a country or place outside Hong Kong as it applies to the service of writs, except that the Registrar may make an order for substituted service of process from a country or place outside Hong Kong on the basis of the process server’s affidavit, certificate or report, without an application being made to him in that behalf. (L.N. 39 of 1999)

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar shall send a certificate, together with a copy of the process, to the consular or other authority, the judicial authorities or the Chief Secretary for Administration, as the case may be, stating— (L.N. 362 of 1997; L.N. 39 of 1999; L.N. 25 of 2020)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when and how service was effected or the reason why service could not be effected, as the case may be;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where appropriate, the amount certified by the taxing master to be the costs of effecting or attempting to effect service.

subsection.content: The certificate under paragraph (6) shall be sealed with the seal of the High Court for use out of the jurisdiction. (25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s4
section.heading: Appointment of process server (O. 69, r. 4)
section.content: The process server for the purposes of this Order shall be the Chief Bailiff.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Obtaining Evidence for Requesting Courts

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation and exercise of jurisdiction (O. 70, r. 1)

subsection.def: In this Order the Ordinance (條例) means the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) and expressions used in this Order which are used in the Ordinance shall have the same meaning as in the Ordinance.

subsection.content: The power of the Court of First Instance to make an order under section 76 or section 76 as extended by section 77B of the Ordinance may be exercised by the Registrar. (L.N. 403 of 1992; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application for order (O. 70, r. 2)

subsection.content: Subject to rule 3 an application for an order under the Ordinance must be made ex parte and must be supported by affidavit.
There shall be exhibited to the affidavit the request in pursuance of which the application is made, and if the request is not in the English language, a translation thereof in that language.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Application by Law Officer (International Law) in certain cases (O. 70 r. 3)
section.leadIn: Where a request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is received by the Chief Secretary for Administration and sent by him to the Registrar with an intimation that effect should be given to the request without requiring an application for that purpose to be made by the agent in Hong Kong of any party to the matter pending or contemplated before the requesting court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is received by the Registrar in pursuance of a Civil Procedure Convention providing for the taking of the evidence of any person in Hong Kong for the assistance of the requesting court, and no person is named in the document as the person who will make the necessary application on behalf of such party,

section.continued: the Registrar shall send the document to the Law Officer (International Law) and the Law Officer (International Law) may make an application for an order under the Ordinance, and take such other steps as may be necessary, to give effect to the request.

editorialNote.content: Please see the transitional provision in rule 2 of L.N. 322 of 1998.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Person to take and manner of taking examination (O. 70, r. 4)

subsection.content: Any order made in pursuance of this Order for the examination of a witness may order the examination to be taken before any fit and proper person nominated by the person applying for the order or before such other qualified person as to the Court seems fit.

If the examination of a witness is to be taken other than by way of a live audio-visual link by the requesting court, subject to rule 6 and to any special directions contained in any order made under this Order for the examination, the examination shall be taken in manner provided by Order 39, rules 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11(1), (2) and (3), and an order may be made under Order 39, rule 14, for payment of the fees and expenses due to the examiner, and those rules shall apply accordingly with any necessary modifications. (L.N. 146 of 2015; 6 of 2025 s. 61)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: If the examination of a witness is to be taken by way of a live audio-visual link by the requesting court, subject to any special directions contained in any order made under this Order for the examination, Order 39, rules 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11(1), (2) and (3) and 14 apply with any necessary modifications. (L.N. 146 of 2015; 6 of 2025 s. 61)

subsection.leadIn: Any order made in pursuance of this Order for the examination of a witness (other than by way of a live audio-visual link by the requesting court) shall permit the cross-examination of the witness by a person who— (L.N. 146 of 2015; 6 of 2025 s. 61)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has the examiner’s approval to do so; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is affected by the examination or his legal representative. (87 of 1997 s. 36)

section.name: s5
section.heading: Dealing with deposition (O. 70, r. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Unless any order made in pursuance of this Order for the examination of any witness otherwise directs, the examiner before whom the examination was taken must send the deposition of that witness to the Registrar, and the Registrar shall— (L.N. 146 of 2015)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a certificate sealed with the Seal of the Court for use out of the jurisdiction identifying the documents annexed thereto, that is to say, the request, the order of the Court for examination and the deposition taken in pursuance of the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the certificate with the documents annexed thereto to the Chief Secretary for Administration, or, where the request was sent to the Registrar by some other person in accordance with a Civil Procedure Convention, to that other person, for transmission to the requesting court. (L.N. 362 of 1997; L.N. 146 of 2015)

subsection.content: Paragraph (1) does not apply if the examination was taken by way of a live audio-visual link by the requesting court. (L.N. 146 of 2015; 6 of 2025 s. 62)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Claim to privilege (O. 70, r. 6)

subsection.content: The provisions of this rule shall have effect where a claim by a witness (other than a witness who is giving evidence to the requesting court by way of a live audio-visual link) to be exempt from giving any evidence on the ground specified in section 77(1)(b) of the Ordinance is not supported or conceded as mentioned in subsection (2) of that section. (L.N. 146 of 2015; 6 of 2025 s. 63)

The examiner may, if he thinks fit, require the witness to give the evidence to which the claim relates and, if the examiner does not do so, the Court may do so, on the ex parte application of the person who obtained the order under section 76.

subsection.leadIn: If such evidence is taken—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it must be contained in a document separate from the remainder of the deposition of the witness;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: on receipt of the statement the Registrar shall, notwithstanding anything in rule 5, retain the document containing the part of the witness’s evidence to which the claim relates and shall send the statement and a request to determine the claim to the requesting court with the documents mentioned in rule 5; (L.N. 146 of 2015)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the claim is rejected by the requesting court, the Registrar shall send to the requesting court the document containing that part of the witness’s evidence to which the claim relates, but if the claim is upheld he shall send the document to the witness, and shall in either case notify the witness and the person who obtained the order under section 76 of the requesting court’s determination. (L.N. 146 of 2015)

section.name: s7
section.heading: Minutes of examination taken by way of live audio-visual link (O. 70, r. 7)

subsection.leadIn: If an order made under this Order is for the examination of a witness by way of a live audio-visual link by the requesting court, the person before whom the examination is taken must be present at the place where the witness is present during the examination and must on the conclusion of the examination— (6 of 2025 s. 64)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: draw up minutes indicating—

subparagraph.content: unless otherwise directed by the order, the identity of the witness;
the date on which, and the time at which, the examination is taken;
the place where the examination is taken; and
whether or not an oath or affirmation has been administered to the witness;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: certify that the minutes were drawn up by the person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: cause the minutes so certified to be sent to the Registrar.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar must, after receiving the minutes sent under paragraph (1)(c), cause the minutes to be sent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the request was sent to the Registrar by the Chief Secretary for Administration, to the Chief Secretary for Administration; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the request was sent to the Registrar by some other person in accordance with a Civil Procedure Convention, to that other person.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Reciprocal Enforcement of Foreign Judgments

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application for registration (O. 71, r. 2)

subsection.content: An application under section 4 of the Foreign Judgments (Reciprocal Enforcement) Ordinance (Cap. 319), (in this Order referred to as the Ordinance) in respect of a judgment to which the Ordinance applies to have the judgment registered in the Court may be made ex parte, but the Court may direct a summons to be issued. (See App. A, Form 63)
If the Court directs a summons to be issued, the summons shall be an originating summons.
An originating summons under this rule shall be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Evidence in support of application (O. 71, r. 3)

subsection.leadIn: An application for registration must be supported by an affidavit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exhibiting the judgment or a verified or certified or otherwise duly authenticated copy thereof and, where the judgment is not in the English language, a translation thereof in that language certified by a notary public or authenticated by affidavit;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: stating to the best of the information or belief of the deponent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the judgment creditor is entitled to enforce the judgment;

subparagraph.name: ii
iv
subparagraph.content: that at the date of the application the judgment can be enforced by execution in the country of the original court and that, if it were registered, the registration would not be, or be liable to be, set aside under section 6 of the Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: specifying the amount of the interest, if any, which under the law of the country of the original court has become due under the judgment up to the time of registration.

subsection.content: Where a judgment sought to be registered is in respect of different matters, and some, but not all, of the provisions of the judgment are such that if those provisions had been contained in separate judgments, those judgments could properly have been registered, the affidavit must state the provisions in respect of which it is sought to register the judgment.

The affidavit must be accompanied by such other evidence with respect to the enforceability of the judgment by execution in the country of the original court, and of the law of that country under which any interest has become due under the judgment, as may be required having regard to the provisions of the Order in Council extending the Ordinance to that country.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Security for costs (O. 71, r. 4)
section.content: Save as otherwise provided by any relevant Order in Council, the Court may order the judgment creditor to give security for the costs of the application for registration and of any proceedings which may be brought to set aside the registration.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Order for registration (O. 71, r. 5)

subsection.content: An order giving leave to register a judgment must be drawn up by, or on behalf of, the judgment creditor.
Except where the order is made on summons, no such order need be served on the judgment debtor.

Every such order shall state the period within which an application may be made to set aside the registration and shall contain a notification that execution on the judgment will not issue until after the expiration of that period.

The Court may, on an application made at any time while it remains competent for any party to apply to have the registration set aside, extend the period (either as originally fixed or as subsequently extended) within which an application to have the registration set aside may be made.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Register of judgments (O. 71, r. 6)

subsection.content: There shall be kept in the Registry under the direction of the Registrar a register of the judgments ordered to be registered under the Ordinance.
There shall be included in each such register particulars of any execution issued on a judgment ordered to be so registered.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Notice of registration (O. 71, r. 7)

subsection.content: Notice of the registration of a judgment must be served on the judgment debtor by delivering it to him personally or by sending it to him at his usual or last known place of abode or business or in such other manner as the Court may direct.
Service of such a notice out of the jurisdiction is permissible without leave, and Order 11, rules 5, 6 and 8, shall apply in relation to such a notice as they apply in relation to notice of a writ.

subsection.leadIn: The notice of registration must state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: full particulars of the judgment registered and the order for registration,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name and address of the judgment creditor or of his solicitor or agent on whom, and at which, any summons issued by the judgment debtor may be served,

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the right of the judgment debtor to apply to have the registration set aside, and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the period within which an application to set aside the registration may be made.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Application to set aside registration (O. 71, r. 9)

subsection.content: An application to set aside the registration of a judgment must be made by summons supported by affidavit.
The Court hearing such application may order any issue between the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor to be tried in any manner in which an issue in an action may be ordered to be tried.

The Court may, either of its own motion or on an application made by the judgment creditor, and if, having regard to all the circumstances of the case it thinks it just to do so, impose such terms, as to giving security or otherwise, as a condition of the further conduct of an application under this rule, as it thinks fit. (L.N. 127 of 1995; L.N. 122 of 2017)

section.name: s10
section.heading: Issue of execution (O. 71, r. 10)

subsection.content: Execution shall not issue on a judgment registered under the Ordinance until after the expiration of the period which, in accordance with rule 5(3), is specified in the order for registration as the period within which an application may be made to set aside the registration or, if that period has been extended by the Court, until after the expiration of that period as so extended.
If an application is made to set aside the registration of a judgment, execution on the judgment shall not issue until after such application is finally determined.

Any party wishing to issue execution on a judgment registered under the Ordinance must produce to the Registrar an affidavit of service of the notice of registration of the judgment and any order made by the Court in relation to the judgment.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Determination of certain questions (O. 71, r. 11)
section.content: If, in any case under the Ordinance, any question arises whether a foreign judgment can be enforced by execution in the country of the original court, or what interest is payable under a foreign judgment under the law of the original court, that question shall be determined in accordance with the provisions in that behalf contained in the Order in Council extending the Ordinance to that country.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Rules to have effect subject to Orders in Council (O. 71, r. 12)
section.content: The foregoing rules shall, in relation to any judgment registered or sought to be registered under the Ordinance, have effect subject to any such provisions contained in the Order in Council extending the Ordinance to the country of the original court as are declared by the Order to be necessary for giving effect to the agreement made between Hong Kong and that country in relation to matters with respect to which there is power to make those rules.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Certified copy of judgment (O. 71, r. 13)

subsection.content: An application under section 12 of the Ordinance for a certified copy of a judgment entered in the Court of First Instance must be made ex parte to the Registrar on affidavit.

subsection.leadIn: An affidavit by which an application under section 12 of the Ordinance is made must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give particulars of the proceedings in which the judgment was obtained;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: state whether the defendant did or did not object to the jurisdiction, and, if so, on what grounds;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: show that the judgment is not subject to any stay of execution;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: state that the time for appealing has expired or, as the case may be, the date on which it will expire and in either case whether notice of appeal against the judgment has been entered; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: state the rate at which the judgment carries interest.

subsection.content: The certified copy of the judgment shall be an office copy sealed with the Seal of the High Court and indorsed with a certificate signed by the Registrar certifying that the copy is a true copy of a judgment obtained in the Court of First Instance of Hong Kong and that it is issued in accordance with section 12 of the Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: There shall also be issued a certificate (signed by the Registrar and sealed with the Seal of the High Court) having annexed to it a copy of the writ, originating summons or other process by which the proceedings were begun, and stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the manner in which the writ or such summons or other process was served on the defendant or that the defendant acknowledged service thereof,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: what objections, if any, were made to the jurisdiction,

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: what pleadings, if any, were served,

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the grounds on which the judgment was based,

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: that the time for appealing has expired or, as the case may be, the date on which it will expire,

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: whether notice of appeal against the judgment has been entered, and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: such other particulars as it may be necessary to give to the court in the foreign country in which it is sought to obtain execution of the judgment,

subsection.continued: and a certificate (signed and sealed as aforesaid) stating the rate at which the judgment carries interest.

section.crossHeading: Enforcement of Recommendations etc. under the Merchant Shipping (Liner Conferences) Ordinance (Cap. 482)

section.name: s41
section.heading: Application for registration (O. 71, r. 41)
section.content: An application under section 10 of the Merchant Shipping (Liner Conferences) Ordinance (Cap. 482) (in this Order referred to as the Liner Conferences Ordinance) for the registration of a recommendation, determination or award shall be made by originating summons, which shall be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Evidence in support of application (O. 71, r. 42)

subsection.leadIn: An application under section 10 of the Liner Conferences Ordinance for the registration of a recommendation must be supported by an affidavit— (L.N. 152 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: where the recommendation and reasons or the record of settlement or the acceptance of the recommendation is not in the English language, a translation thereof into English certified by a notary public or authenticated by affidavit;
