paragraph.content: a summary by convenient periods of any expenditure that supported the use of the processes mentioned in subparagraphs (a) and (c).

subsection.content: Despite paragraphs (2) and (3), a party may apply to the Court under Order 24, rule 3 or 7, for an order for discovery of any document in an exempt class, but the Court may only make the order if it considers it just to do so.

If a party (Party A) who produces for inspection a document that belongs to an exempt class is requested in writing by any other party (Party B) to serve a supplementary list of all other documents that belong to the same class as the document produced for inspection, Party A must serve on Party B the supplementary list within 14 days after receiving the request unless the Court otherwise orders.
This rule does not create any privilege from production in a document that belongs to an exempt class.
This rule does not limit the Court’s power to limit the discovery of documents on any other ground.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: convenient period (便利時期), in relation to an article, a product or a process, means a period of time for the convenient illustration of the commercial success of a patent relating to the article, product or process;
equivalent period (對等時期), in relation to a convenient period, means a period that is equivalent to the convenient period.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Experiments (O. 103, r. 23)

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: patent infringement proceedings (whether or not relief in relation to any other matter is claimed);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings under section 89;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: proceedings in which a declaration in relation to a patent is sought under section 90; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: proceedings in which the validity of a patent is put in issue.

subsection.content: A party to any proceedings that are begun by writ who wishes to establish any facts by experimental proof must, within 21 days after being served with a list of documents under rule 22, serve on any other party a notice to establish facts.

subsection.leadIn: A party to any proceedings that are begun by originating summons who wishes to establish any facts by experimental proof must serve on any other party a notice to establish facts within 21 days after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if affidavit evidence in reply is served before the expiry of the period for the service of such affidavit evidence (specified period)—the date on which it is served; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if no affidavit evidence in reply is served before the expiry of the specified period—the expiry of the specified period.

subsection.leadIn: A notice to establish facts must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the facts that the party wishes to establish; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give full particulars of the experiments by which the party proposes to establish the facts.

subsection.content: A party on whom a notice to establish facts is served (Party A) must, within 21 days after service of the notice, serve a notice in reply on the party who served the notice to establish facts (Party B).
A notice in reply mentioned in paragraph (5) must, in respect of each fact specified in the notice to establish facts, state whether the fact is admitted or not.
Party A may request Party B to show or carry out any of the experiments identified in the notice to establish facts in presence of Party A or a person designated by Party A.

crossHeading.b: X. General Provisions on Amendment of Patents

section.name: s24
section.heading: Application for purposes of section 102 (application to amend specification of patent in infringement or revocation proceedings) (O. 103, r. 24)

subsection.content: An application by the proprietor of a patent (applicant) to amend the specification of the patent in any proceeding in which the validity of the patent is put in issue for the purposes of section 102 must be made by summons.

subsection.leadIn: The applicant must state in the summons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the applicant will contend that the patent is valid based on the claims in the specification; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so, that the application is made as an alternative if the contention fails.

subsection.leadIn: Within 7 days after the issue of the summons, the applicant must serve on the Registrar of Patents and the other parties to the proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the summons;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of the specification of the patent showing in coloured ink the amendment sought; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any translation that the Court may require.

subsection.leadIn: The applicant must, within 1 month after the issue of the summons or within a further period that the Court may direct, publish in the Gazette an advertisement that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifies the patent concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that on giving prior notice to the applicant, the full particulars of the amendment that the applicant intends to seek in the application are available for inspection within 28 days after publication of the advertisement during ordinary business hours at a place in Hong Kong designated by the applicant;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: sets out the applicant’s address for service in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: sets out the matters provided for in paragraphs (5) and (6).

subsection.leadIn: If a person (other than a party to the proceedings) intends to oppose the application, the person must, within 42 days after publication of the advertisement, send a notice by registered post to the applicant at the applicant’s address for service set out in the advertisement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: indicating an intention to oppose; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specifying the person’s address for service in Hong Kong.

subsection.content: A person who sends a notice under paragraph (5) (intending opponent) is, subject to the Court’s directions as to costs, entitled to be heard at the hearing of the application.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the expiry of the period specified in paragraph (5), the applicant must serve on every intending opponent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the summons;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of the specification of the patent showing in coloured ink the amendment sought; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any translation that the Court may require.

subsection.content: Without limiting Order 65, rule 5, service of a document on an intending opponent under paragraph (7) may be effected by sending the document by registered post to the intending opponent at the address for service specified in the notice sent under paragraph (5).

subsection.leadIn: If the Court makes an order allowing the specification of the patent to be amended, the applicant must, within 14 days after the date of sealing the order, file with the Registrar of Patents—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sealed copy of the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (10), a new specification as amended, which must be prepared in accordance with—

subparagraph.content: section 12 of the Patents Rules if the patent is a standard patent (R);
section 31Q of the Patents Rules if the patent is a standard patent (O); or
section 62 of the Patents Rules if the patent is a short-term patent.

subsection.content: The Court may order that the filing of a copy of the specification with the amendment marked on it is sufficient compliance with the requirement under paragraph (9)(b).
The Registrar of Patents must cause a copy of the order to be published at least once in the official journal.

crossHeading.b: XI. Proceedings Arising from References by Registrar of Patents

section.name: s25
section.heading: Proceedings for the purposes of section 44(5), 48(4), 49(2)(b), 127E(3) or 133(1)(b) (O. 103, r. 25)

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the Registrar of Patents—

subparagraph.content: refers to the Court under section 49(2)(b) a question of whether an invention is a patentable invention;
refers to the Court under section 127E(3) opposition proceedings against a request to amend the specification of a short-term patent: or

subparagraph.leadIn: refers to the Court under section 133(1)(b)—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a question referred to the Registrar of Patents under section 13(1), 14(5), 37H(1) or 37K(7); or

subparagraph.name: B

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Registrar of Patents has given to the parties and the Court written notice of the decision of such reference (notice of decision) under section 37A(2), 40A(2), 41AAI(2), 81W(2), 92A(2) or 92B(2) of the Patents Rules.

subsection.leadIn: If the person who brought the previous proceedings (intending plaintiff or applicant) wishes to commence proceedings before the Court in relation to the application, matter, question or opposition proceedings, the intending plaintiff or applicant must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within the specified period, take out the originating summons by which the proceedings are to be begun; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within 7 days after the issue of the originating summons, serve a copy of the originating summons on the Registrar of Patents.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, rule 5, 6, 7 or 19 does not apply to the proceedings commenced under paragraph (2) in relation to a question or an application mentioned in paragraph (1)(a)(iii) or (v).
Proceedings commenced under paragraph (2) in relation to an application, a matter, a question or opposition proceedings are to be treated as the continuation of the previous proceedings.

As soon as practicable after being served with a copy of the originating summons, the Registrar of Patents must, for the purpose of the proceedings commenced under paragraph (2), file with the Court any document or other thing that was filed with the Registrar of Patents for the purpose of the previous proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this rule—
subsection.def: previous proceedings (過往法律程序) means the proceedings brought before the Registrar of Patents for determination of an application, a matter, a question or opposition proceedings under section 13(1), 14(5), 37H(1), 37K(7), 44(4), 46(2)(b) or (c), 48(1), 49(1) or 127E(2)(b) (as the case may be);

specified period (指明限期) means—(a)a period of 1 month after the date of the notice of decision given under section 37A(2), 40A(2), 41AAI(2), 81W(2), 92A(2) or 92B(2) of the Patents Rules (as the case may be); or(b)such period as may be extended by the Registrar of Patents under section 100AA of the Patents Rules.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Appointment of scientific adviser (O. 103, r. 26)

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings under the Ordinance, the Court may at any time, either of its own motion or on application of any party, appoint an independent scientific adviser—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to assist the Court; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to inquire into and report on any question of fact, or of opinion, not involving a question of law or construction.

subsection.content: Order 40, rules 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 apply, with necessary modifications, in relation to an independent scientific adviser appointed under paragraph (1) and a report made by the adviser as they apply in relation to a court expert appointed under rule 1 of that Order and a report made by the expert.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Service of documents on proprietors and applicants (O. 103, r. 27)

subsection.leadIn: This rule applies to the service of a document on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the proprietor of a patent in any proceedings relating to the patent before the proprietor has provided an address for service in an acknowledgement of service under Order 12, rule 3(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant of a patent application in any proceedings relating to the patent application before the applicant has provided an address for service in an acknowledgement of service under that rule.

subsection.leadIn: For the service of an originating process, or any other document that is required to be or may be served in accordance with Order 10, on any of the persons mentioned in paragraph (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: Order 10 has effect as if in rule 1(2) of that Order—

subparagraph.content: the reference to service on a defendant were a reference to service on the person; and

subparagraph.leadIn: the reference to the usual or last known address of the defendant were a reference—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: to the usual or last known address of the person;

subparagraph.name: B
C
subparagraph.content: if the person is an applicant of a patent application that has not been published—to the person’s address for service communicated under section 91A(3) of the Patents Rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Order 65 has effect as if, in rule 3(2) of that Order, the reference to Order 10, rule 1(2) were a reference to that rule 1(2) as construed in accordance with subparagraph (a).

subsection.content: For the service of a document other than those mentioned in paragraph (2) on any of the persons mentioned in paragraph (1), Order 65 has effect as if the addresses specified in rule 5(2)(a), (b), (c) and (d) of that Order included the person’s address for service as shown in the register in relation to the patent or the patent application concerned.

A document served on any of the persons mentioned in paragraph (1) at the person’s address for service shown in the register in relation to the patent or the patent application concerned, or at the person’s address for service communicated under section 91A(3) of the Patents Rules, in accordance with this rule is to be treated as having been duly served within the jurisdiction on the person even if the person is not within the jurisdiction on the date of service mentioned in Order 10, rule 1(3)(a).

section.name: s28
section.heading: Filing of orders etc. with Registrar of Patents (O. 103, r. 28)
section.content: Without limiting rules 7(12) and 24(9), if the Court has made an order, a direction or a declaration, or has granted a certificate under the Ordinance in favour of a person, the person or, if there is more than one such person, the person directed by the Court, must file a sealed copy of the order, direction, declaration or certificate with the Registrar of Patents within 14 days after the date of sealing the order, direction, declaration or certificate.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Transitional (O. 103, r. 29)
section.content: For proceedings that are brought under the Ordinance but are pending before the Court immediately before the commencement date* of the Rules of the High Court (Amendment) (No. 2) Rules 2025 (new rules), the Court may, of its own motion or on application of a party to the proceedings, give directions that the new rules, or any part of it, are to be applied to the further conduct of the proceedings.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Proceedings relating to Solicitors: The Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159)

section.name: s1
section.heading: Definitions (O. 106, r. 1)
section.leadIn: In this Order—
section.def: appeal (上訴) means an appeal against any order made by the disciplinary tribunal on an application or complaint under the Ordinance; (L.N. 275 of 1998)
disciplinary tribunal (紀律審裁組) means the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal constituted in accordance with section 9B of the Ordinance; (L.N. 275 of 1998)
the Ordinance (條例) means the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159).

section.name: s2
section.heading: Jurisdiction under Part VI of the Ordinance exercisable by judge in chambers, etc. (O. 106, r. 2)

subsection.content: Any application to the Court under Part VI of the Ordinance may be disposed of in chambers.
The jurisdiction of the Court under Part VI of the Ordinance may be exercised by a judge in chambers.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Power to order solicitor to deliver cash account, etc. (O. 106, r. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where the relationship of solicitor and client exists or has existed, the Court may, on the application of the client or his personal representative, make an order for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the delivery by the solicitor of a cash account;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the payment or delivery up by the solicitor of money or securities;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: the payment into or lodging in court of any such moneys or securities.

subsection.content: An application for an order under this rule must be made by originating summons.

If the defendant alleges that he has a claim for costs, the Court may make such order for the taxation and payment, or securing the payment, thereof and the protection of the defendant’s lien, if any, as the Court thinks fit.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Form of originating summons (O. 106, r. 5)
section.content: An originating summons by which an application under the Ordinance, or any application for an order under rule 3, is made shall be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Service of documents (O. 106, r. 10)

subsection.content: Any document required to be served on the Society in proceedings under this Order shall be served by sending it by prepaid post to the secretary of the Society.

Subject to paragraph (1), any document not required to be served personally which is to be served on a defendant to proceedings under this Order shall, unless the Court otherwise directs, be deemed to be properly served by sending it by prepaid post to the defendant at his last known address.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Constitution of the Court of Appeal to hear appeals (O. 106, r. 11)
section.content: Every appeal shall be heard by the Court of Appeal consisting, unless the Chief Justice otherwise directs, of not less than 3 judges.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Service of notice of motion (O. 106, r. 12)

subsection.content: Unless the Court otherwise orders, the notice of the originating motion by which an appeal is brought must be served on every party to the proceedings before the disciplinary tribunal and the Society. (L.N. 275 of 1998; L.N. 122 of 2017)
The notice must be served within 21 days from the day on which the order appealed against is pronounced. (L.N. 275 of 1998)

section.name: s13
section.heading: Society to produce certain documents (O. 106, r. 13)

subsection.leadIn: Within 7 days after being served with notice of the originating motion by which an appeal is brought the Society must lodge in the Registry 3 copies of each of the following documents—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the order appealed against, prefaced by the statement of the disciplinary tribunal’s findings required by section 12 of the Ordinance,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any document lodged by a party with the disciplinary tribunal which is relevant to a matter in issue on the appeal, and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the transcript of the shorthand note, or, as the case may be, the note taken by the chairman of the disciplinary tribunal, of the evidence in the proceedings before the tribunal. (L.N. 275 of 1998)

subsection.content: At the hearing of the appeal the Court shall direct by whom the costs incurred in complying with paragraph (1) are to be borne and may order them to be paid to the Society by one of the parties notwithstanding that the Society does not appear at the hearing.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Restriction on requiring security for costs (O. 106, r. 14)
section.content: No person other than an appellant who was the applicant in the proceedings before the disciplinary tribunal or, in the case of an application to that tribunal by a solicitor to procure his name to be removed from the roll, was an objector, shall be ordered to give security for the costs of an appeal.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Disciplinary tribunal’s opinion may be required (O. 106, r. 15)
section.content: The Court may direct the disciplinary tribunal to furnish the Court with a written statement of their opinion on the case which is the subject-matter of an appeal or on any question arising therein, and where such a direction is given, the clerk to the disciplinary tribunal must as soon as may be lodge 3 copies of such statement in the Registry and at the same time send a copy to each of the parties to the appeal.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Persons entitled to be heard on appeal (O. 106, r. 16)
section.content: A person who has not been served with notice of the originating motion by which an appeal is brought but who desires to be heard in opposition to the appeal shall, if he appears to the Court to be a proper person to be so heard, be entitled to be so heard.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Discontinuance of appeal (O. 106, r. 17)

subsection.content: An appellant may at any time discontinue his appeal by serving notice of discontinuance on the clerk to the disciplinary tribunal and every other party to the appeal and, if the appeal has been entered, by lodging a copy of the notice in the Registry. (L.N. 275 of 1998)

Where an appeal has been discontinued in accordance with paragraph (1), it shall be treated as having been dismissed with an order for payment by the appellant of the costs of and incidental to the appeal, including any costs incurred by the Society in complying with rule 13(1).

section.name: s113
section.heading: Summary Proceedings for Possession of Land

section.name: s1
section.content: Where a person claims possession of land which he alleges is occupied solely by a person or persons (not being a tenant or tenants holding over after the termination of the tenancy) who entered into or remained in occupation without his licence or consent or that of any predecessor in title of his, the proceedings may be brought by originating summons in accordance with the provisions of this Order.

section.name: s1A
section.heading: Jurisdiction of masters (O. 113, r. 1A)
section.content: Proceedings under this Order may be heard and determined by a master, who may refer them to a judge if he thinks they should properly be decided by the judge.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Form of originating summons (O. 113, r. 2)
section.content: The originating summons shall be in Form No. 11A in Appendix A and no acknowledgment of service of it shall be required.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Affidavit in support (O. 113, r. 3)
section.leadIn: The plaintiff shall file in support of the originating summons an affidavit stating—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his interest in the land;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which the land has been occupied without licence or consent and in which his claim to possession arises; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that he does not know the name of any person occupying the land who is not named in the summons.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Service of originating summons (O. 113, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Where any person in occupation of the land is named in the originating summons, the summons together with a copy of the affidavit in support shall be served on him—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: personally, or

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: by sending a copy of the summons and of the affidavit by ordinary post to him at the premises, or (L.N. 122 of 2017)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by leaving a copy of the summons and of the affidavit, or sending them to him, at the premises, or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in such other manner as the Court may direct.

subsection.leadIn: The summons shall, in addition to being served on the named defendants (if any) in accordance with paragraph (1), be served, unless the Court otherwise directs, by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affixing a copy of the summons and a copy of the affidavit to the main door or other conspicuous part of the premises, and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if practicable, inserting through the letter-box at the premises a copy of the summons and a copy of the affidavit enclosed in a sealed envelope addressed to “the occupiers”.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: Every copy of an originating summons for service under paragraph (1) or (2) shall be sealed with the seal of the High Court. (25 of 1998 s. 2)
Order 28, rule 3, shall not apply to proceedings under this Order.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Application by occupier to be made a party (O. 113, r. 5)
section.content: Without prejudice to Order 15, rules 6 and 10, any person not named as a defendant who is in occupation of the land and wishes to be heard on the question whether an order for possession should be made may apply at any stage of the proceedings to be joined as a defendant.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Order for possession (O. 113, r. 6)

subsection.content: A final order shall, except in case of urgency and by leave of the Court, not be made less than 5 clear days after the date of service. (L.N. 165 of 1992)
An order for possession in proceedings under this Order shall be in Form No. 42A in Appendix A.

Nothing in this Order shall prevent the Court from ordering possession to be given on a specified date, in exercise of any power which could have been exercised if possession had been claimed in an action begun by writ.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Writ of possession (O. 113, r. 7)

subsection.leadIn: Order 45, rule 3(2), shall not apply in relation to an order for possession under this Order but no writ of possession to enforce such an order shall be issued after the expiry of 3 months from the date of the order without the leave of the Court.
subsection.continued: An application for leave may be made ex parte unless the Court otherwise directs.

subsection.content: The writ of possession shall be in Form No. 66A in Appendix A.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Setting aside order (O. 113, r. 8)
section.content: The judge may, on such terms as he thinks just, set aside or vary any order made in proceedings under this Order.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Commissioners for Oaths

section.name: s1
section.heading: Appointment of commissioners for oaths (O. 114, r. 1)

subsection.content: The Chief Justice may, by a commission signed by him, appoint fit and proper persons to be commissioners to administer oaths and take declarations, affirmations, and attestations of honour, and may revoke any such appointment. (L.N. 122 of 2017)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The power of appointment under paragraph (1) may, by a notice in writing signed by the Chief Justice, be delegated to the Registrar. (L.N. 167 of 1994)
Every person so appointed shall be styled a commissioner for oaths and shall have all the powers and discharge all the duties which now belong to the office of a commissioner to administer oaths.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Officers of the court to administer oaths (O. 114, r. 2)
section.content: Every person who, being an officer of or performing duties in relation to the Court, is for the time being so authorized by the Court or by or in pursuance of any rules or orders regulating the procedure of the Court, and every person directed to take an examination in any cause or matter in the Court, shall have authority to administer any oath or take any affidavit required for any purpose connected with his duties.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405)

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 115, r. 1)

subsection.def: In this Order the Ordinance (條例) means the Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance (Cap. 405), and a section referred to by number means the section so numbered in the Ordinance.

subsection.content: Expressions used in this Order which are used in the Ordinance have the same meanings in this Order as in the Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Assignment of proceedings (O. 115, r. 2)
section.content: Subject to Order 32, rule 18, and to rule 12, the jurisdiction of the Court under the Ordinance shall be exercised by a judge of the Court in chambers notwithstanding that the originating process is an originating summons.

section.name: s2A
section.heading: Application for confiscation order where person has died or absconded (O. 115, r. 2A)

subsection.content: An application for a confiscation order under section 3 where the defendant has died or absconded shall be made by the Secretary for Justice. (L.N. 152 of 2008)
An application under paragraph (1) may be made by originating summons in Form No. 10 in Appendix A. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

section.name: s3
section.heading: Application for restraint order or charging order (O. 115, r. 3)

subsection.content: An application for a restraint order under section 10 or for a charging order under section 11 (to either of which may be joined an application for the appointment of a receiver) shall be made by the Secretary for Justice ex parte. (L.N. 296 of 1996; L.N. 362 of 1997; L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: An application under paragraph (1) may be made by originating summons in Form No. 10 in Appendix A. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: state, as the case may be, the grounds for believing that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the defendant has benefited from drug trafficking; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Court of First Instance will be satisfied as specified in section 15(1A); (89 of 1995 s. 30; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: state, as the case may be—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: that, whether by the laying of an information or otherwise, a person is to be charged with a drug trafficking offence;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the defendant where section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (7) is applicable; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: that an application has been made under section 15(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against the defendant; (89 of 1995 s. 30)

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: where proceedings have not been instituted, verify that the Secretary for Justice is to have the conduct of the proposed proceedings; (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: where proceedings have not been instituted, indicate when it is intended that they should be instituted.

subsection.content: An originating summons under paragraph (1A) shall be entitled in the matter of the defendant, naming him, and in the matter of the Ordinance, and all subsequent documents in the matter shall be so entitled. (L.N. 152 of 2008)
Unless the Court otherwise directs, an affidavit under paragraph (2) may contain statements of information or belief with the sources and grounds thereof.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Restraint order and charging order (O. 115, r. 4)

subsection.content: A restraint order may be made subject to conditions and exceptions, including but not limited to conditions relating to the indemnifying of third parties against expenses incurred in complying with the order, and exceptions relating to reasonable living expenses and reasonable legal expenses of the defendant, but the Secretary for Justice shall not be required to give an undertaking to abide by any order as to damages sustained by the defendant as a result of the restraint order. (89 of 1995 s. 30)

Unless the Court otherwise directs, a restraint order made ex parte shall have effect until a day which shall be fixed for the hearing inter partes of the application and a charging order shall be an order to show cause, imposing the charge until such day.

Where a restraint order is made the Secretary for Justice shall serve copies of the order and of the affidavit in support on the defendant and on all other named persons restrained by the order and shall notify all other persons or bodies affected by the order of its terms.

Where a charging order is made the Secretary for Justice shall, unless the Court otherwise directs, serve copies of the order and of the affidavit in support on the defendant and, where the property to which the order relates is held by another person, on that person and shall serve a copy of the order on such of the persons or bodies specified in Order 50, rule 2(1)(b) to (d) as shall be appropriate.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Discharge or variation of order (O. 115, r. 5)

subsection.content: Any person or body on whom a restraint order or a charging order is served or who is notified of such an order may apply by summons to discharge or vary the order.

The summons and any affidavit in support shall be served on the Secretary for Justice and, where he is not the applicant, on the defendant, not less than 2 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons. (L.N. 296 of 1996; L.N. 362 of 1997)

Upon the Court being notified that proceedings for the offences have been concluded or that the amount payment of which is secured by a charging order has been paid into court, any restraint order or charging order, as the case may be, shall be discharged.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Further application by Secretary for Justice (O. 115, r. 6)

subsection.leadIn: Where a restraint order or a charging order has been made the Secretary for Justice may apply (and, if so, by summons) or, where the case is one of urgency, ex parte— (L.N. 296 of 1996; L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to discharge or vary such order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a restraint order or a charging order in respect of other realisable property; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the appointment of a receiver.

subsection.content: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit which, where the application is for a restraint order or a charging order, shall to the best of the deponent’s ability give full particulars of the realisable property in respect of which the order is sought and specify the person or persons holding such property.

The summons and affidavit in support shall be served on the defendant and, where one has been appointed in the matter, on the receiver, not less than 2 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons. (L.N. 296 of 1996)
Rule 4(3) and (4) shall apply to the service of restraint orders and charging orders respectively made under this rule on persons other than the defendant.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Realisation of property (O. 115, r. 7)

subsection.content: An application under section 12 must be made by the Secretary for Justice. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The application may, where there have been proceedings against the defendant in the Court of First Instance, be made by summons and may otherwise be made by originating summons in Form No. 10 in Appendix A. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: The summons or originating summons, as the case may be, shall be served with the evidence in support not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons on— (L.N. 152 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person holding any interest in the realisable property to which the application relates; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the receiver, where one has been appointed in the matter.

subsection.content: The application shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall, to the best of the deponent’s ability, give full particulars of the realisable property to which it relates and specify the person or persons holding such property, and a copy of the confiscation order, of any certificate issued by the Court under section 6(2) and of any charging order made in the matter shall be exhibited to such affidavit.
The Court may, on an application under section 12, exercise the power conferred by section 13(1) to direct the making of payments by the receiver.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Receivers (O. 115, r. 8)

subsection.content: Subject to this rule, the provisions of Order 30, rules 2 to 8 shall apply where a receiver is appointed in pursuance of a charging order or under section 10 or 12.

Where the receiver proposed to be appointed has been appointed receiver in other proceedings under the Ordinance, it shall not be necessary for an affidavit of fitness to be sworn or for the receiver to give security, unless the Court otherwise orders.

Where a receiver has fully paid the amount payable under the confiscation order and any sums remain in his hands, he shall apply by case management summons as to the distribution of such sums. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: A summons under paragraph (3) shall be served with any evidence in support not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person who held property realised by the receiver.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Variation of confiscation order (O. 115, r. 9)

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice or defendant may apply by summons for an order under section 15(1).

subsection.leadIn: A summons under paragraph (1) shall be served, with any supporting evidence, not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the Secretary for Justice is making the application, the defendant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the defendant is making the application, the Secretary for Justice,

subsection.continued: and, in either case, on the receiver, where one has been appointed in the matter.

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice may apply by summons for an order under section 15(1A). (89 of 1995 s. 30)

section.name: s10
section.heading: Compensation (O. 115, r. 10)
section.content: An application for an order under section 27 shall be made by summons, which shall be served, with any supporting evidence, on the person alleged to be in default and on the Secretary for Justice not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Disclosure of information (O. 115, r. 11)

subsection.content: An application under section 23 shall be made by the Secretary for Justice by summons, which shall state the nature of the order sought and whether material sought to be disclosed is to be disclosed to a receiver appointed under section 10 or 12 or in pursuance of a charging order or to an authorized officer. (L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: The summons and affidavit in support shall be served on the public body—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the public body is a Government Department, in accordance with Order 77, rule 4.

subsection.content: The affidavit in support of an application under paragraph (1) shall state the grounds for believing that the conditions in section 23(4) and, if appropriate, section 23(7) are fulfilled.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Exercise of powers under section 29 (O. 115, r. 12)
section.content: The powers conferred on the Court by section 29 may be exercised by a judge in chambers and a Master.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Application for registration (O. 115, r. 13)
section.content: An application for registration of an external confiscation order under section 29(1) may be ex parte.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Evidence in support of application under section 29(1) (O. 115, r. 15)
section.leadIn: An application for registration of an external confiscation order must be supported by an affidavit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exhibiting the order or a verified or certified or otherwise duly authenticated copy thereof and, where the order is not in the English language, a translation thereof into English certified by a notary public or authenticated by affidavit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: stating—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the order is in force and is not subject to appeal;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, the order was made did not appear in the proceedings, that he received notice of the proceedings, in accordance with the law of the designated country concerned, in sufficient time to enable him to defend them; (89 of 1995 s. 30)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of money, either that at the date of the application the sum payable under the order has not been paid or the amount which remains unpaid, as may be appropriate, or, in the case of other property, the property which has not been recovered; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: to the best of the deponent’s knowledge, particulars of what property the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, the order was made holds in Hong Kong, giving the source of the deponent’s knowledge. (89 of 1995 s. 30)

section.name: s16
section.heading: Register of orders (O. 115, r. 16)

subsection.content: The Registrar shall keep a register of the orders registered under the Ordinance.

There shall be included in such register particulars of any variation or setting aside of a registration, of any variation, satisfaction or discharge of a registered order, and of any execution issued on such an order.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Notice of registration (O. 115, r. 17)

subsection.content: Notice of the registration of an order must be served on the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, it was obtained by delivering it to him personally or by sending it to him at his usual or last known address or place of business or in such other manner as the Court may direct. (89 of 1995 s. 30)
Service of such a notice out of the jurisdiction is permissible without leave, and Order 11, rules 5, 6 and 8 shall apply in relation to such a notice as they apply in relation to a writ.
The notice shall state the period within which an application may be made to vary or set aside the registration and that the order will not be enforced until after the expiration of that period.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Application to vary or set aside registration (O. 115, r. 18)
section.content: An application by the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, an order was made to vary or set aside the registration of an order must be made to a judge by summons supported by affidavit.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Enforcement of order (O. 115, r. 19)

subsection.content: An order registered under the Ordinance shall not be enforced until after the expiration of the period specified in accordance with rule 17(3) or, if that period has been extended by the Court, until after the expiration of the period so extended.
If an application is made under rule 18, an order shall not be enforced until after such application is determined.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Variation, satisfaction and discharge of registered order (O. 115, r. 20)
section.content: Upon the Court being notified by the applicant for registration that an order which has been registered has been varied, satisfied or discharged, particulars of the variation, satisfaction or discharge, as the case may be, shall be entered in the register.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Rules to have effect subject to orders (O. 115, r. 21)
section.content: Rules 12 to 20 shall have effect subject to the provisions of any order made under section 28.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Statement relating to drug trafficking (O. 115, r. 22)

subsection.content: Where the Secretary for Justice or the defendant proposes to tender to the Court any statement or other document under section 5 he shall give a copy thereof as soon as practicable to the defendant or the Secretary for Justice, as the case may be, and to the appropriate officer of the Court. (89 of 1995 s. 30; L.N. 122 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: Any statement tendered to the Court by the Secretary for Justice under section 5(1) shall include the following particulars, namely— (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name of the defendant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of the person who made the statement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: such information known to the person who made the statement as is relevant to—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: the determination whether the defendant has benefited from drug trafficking;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the assessment of the value of the defendant’s proceeds of drug trafficking. (89 of 1995 s. 30)

section.name: s23
section.heading: Investigation into drug trafficking—discharge and variation of orders (O. 115, r. 23)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: An authorized officer shall make an application for an order under section 20 or a warrant under section 21 ex parte to a judge by laying an information on oath. (L.N. 142 of 1990)

Where an order under section 20 has been made, the person required to comply with it may apply in writing to the appropriate officer of the Court for the order to be discharged or varied, and on hearing such an application the Court may discharge the order or make such variations to it as it thinks fit. (L.N. 122 of 2017)

Subject to paragraph (3), where a person proposes to make an application under paragraph (1) for the discharge or variation of an order, he shall give a copy of the application, not later than 48 hours before the making of the application, to the authorized officer by whom the application for an order was made, or if such officer is not known or cannot be found, to another authorized officer, together with a notice indicating the time and place at which the application for discharge or variation is to be made.

The Court may direct that paragraph (2) need not be complied with if it is satisfied that the person making the application has good reason to seek a discharge or variation of the order as soon as possible and it is not practicable to comply with that paragraph.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Application for continued detention of seized property (O. 115, r. 24)

subsection.content: An application under section 24C(2) for an order to authorize the continued detention of seized property may be made by originating summons in Form No. 10 in Appendix A. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: state the grounds for suspecting that the seized property is specified property; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: give particulars, in terms of the matters referred to in section 24C(2)(b), as to why the continued detention of the seized property is justified.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Order for continued detention of seized property (O. 115, r. 25)

subsection.content: Where an order is made under section 24C(2), the applicant shall, as soon as is practicable, serve a copy of the order on each person affected by the order.
An order under section 24C(2) shall be in Form No. 108 in Appendix A.

subsection.leadIn: In rules 26(3) and (4), 27, 28(2) and 29(3) and (4), affected person (受影響的人), in relation to any summons or order referred to in those rules, means a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on whom a copy of an order made under section 24C(2) has been served pursuant to paragraph (1) where the seized property (or any part thereof) the subject of the summons or first-mentioned order is or was the subject of the second-mentioned order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in respect of whom the Court has made an order under rule 31 in connection with the summons or first-mentioned order.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Application for further detention of seized property (O. 115, r. 26)

subsection.content: An application under section 24C(3) for an order to authorize the further detention of seized property shall be made by summons in the proceedings commenced under rule 24.

subsection.leadIn: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the grounds for suspecting that the seized property is specified property; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give particulars, in terms of the matters referred to in section 24C(2)(b), as to why the continued detention of the seized property is justified.

subsection.content: The summons and the affidavit in support shall be served on each affected person not less than 5 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

subsection.leadIn: Affidavit evidence in response to the summons shall be served by an affected person on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Secretary for Justice on behalf of the applicant; and (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each other affected person,

subsection.continued: not less than 2 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Order for further detention of seized property (O. 115, r. 27)
section.content: Where an order is made under section 24C(3), the applicant shall, as soon as is practicable, serve a copy of the order on each affected person.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Application for release of seized property (O. 115, r. 28)

subsection.content: An application under section 24C(4)(a) for the release of seized property detained by an order under section 24C(2) or (3) shall be made by summons which shall state the grounds on which the application is made.

subsection.leadIn: The summons and any affidavit in support shall be served on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Secretary for Justice on behalf of the authorized officer who obtained the order by virtue of which the seized property is detained; and (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each other affected person,

subsection.continued: not less than 5 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

subsection.leadIn: Any affidavit in opposition to the summons shall be served on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person who made the application under paragraph (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each of the other persons referred to in paragraph (2)(a) and (b),

subsection.continued: not less than 2 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Application for forfeiture of seized property (O. 115, r. 29)

subsection.content: An application under section 24D(1) for the forfeiture of seized property shall be made by summons in the proceedings under which any order under rule 24 has been obtained.

subsection.leadIn: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall state the grounds for believing that the seized property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in whole or in part directly or indirectly represents any person’s proceeds of drug trafficking;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been used in drug trafficking; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is intended for use in drug trafficking.

subsection.content: The summons and the affidavit in support referred to in paragraphs (1) and (2) shall be served on each affected person not less than 14 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

subsection.leadIn: Any affidavit in opposition to the summons shall be served by an affected person on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Secretary for Justice on behalf of the applicant; and (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each other affected person,

subsection.continued: not less than 5 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Release of seized property (O. 115, r. 30)
section.leadIn: Where in relation to any seized property—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 24C(2) expires without an order being made under section 24C(3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under section 24C(3) expires without a further order being made thereunder; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a direction is obtained under section 24C(4),

section.continued: then, unless the Court has directed that an issue be stated and tried as between affected persons, the property shall be forthwith released on such terms, if any, as the Court thinks fit to the person from whom the property was seized or to such other person as appears to be entitled to it.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Joinder and payment into Court (O. 115, r. 31)

subsection.content: Without prejudice to its powers under Order 15, rule 6, the Court may either of its own motion or on application order that any person who may be affected by any order made by it be joined as a party to the proceedings.
The Court may order that the property which is the subject of an application or order shall be paid into or lodged in Court on such terms as it thinks fit.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Service of documents (O. 115, r. 32)

subsection.content: Without prejudice to Order 65, any documents required to be served on a party under rules 25 to 29 may be served in accordance with the provisions of this rule.

Where documents are required to be served on a party from whom property has been seized and that party has provided an authorized officer with an address or facsimile number at which any such document may be served, the documents may be served by leaving them at or sending them by registered mail to that address or by sending it by facsimile to the number provided.

If that party has refused to provide an authorized officer with any such address or facsimile number and there is no other method of serving him or if it is otherwise not possible to serve a party, the documents may be served on that party by exhibiting them on a notice board at a place to which the public have access on the ground floor of the High Court Building but where any application made under rule 25, 26, 27, 28 or 29 is so served, the applicant shall state in his affidavit of service why this method of service has been adopted and the Court shall consider whether to give directions for some other form of service (including substituted service) by the applicant. (25 of 1998 s. 2)

A body corporate which is not incorporated in Hong Kong and which is not a registered non-Hong Kong company as defined by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) may be served by leaving the document to be served at or by sending it by registered mail to the registered office or principal place of business of that body corporate. (28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

section.name: s33
section.heading: Power to extend or abridge time (O. 115, r. 33)
section.content: Rules 26(3) and (4), 28(2) and (3), and 29(3) and (4) shall not operate to prejudice the power of the Court under Order 3, rule 5, to extend or abridge the period within which a person is required or authorized by any of those rules to do any act in any proceedings.

section.name: s115A
section.heading: Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Ordinance (Cap. 525)

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 115A, r. 1)

subsection.def: In this Order the Ordinance (條例) means the Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Ordinance (Cap. 525), and a section referred to by number in rules 3 to 12 means the section so numbered in the Ordinance and in rules 13 to 18 means the section so numbered in Schedule 2 to the Ordinance. (L.N. 122 of 2017)

subsection.content: Expressions used in this Order which are used in the Ordinance (including Schedule 2 to the Ordinance) have the same meanings in this Order as in the Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Assignment of proceedings (O. 115A, r. 2)
section.content: Subject to rule 3, the jurisdiction of the Court under the Ordinance shall be exercised by a judge of the Court in chambers.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Exercise of powers under section 28 (O. 115A, r. 3)
section.content: The powers conferred on the Court by section 28 may be exercised by a judge in chambers and a Master.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Application for registration (O. 115A, r. 4)
section.content: An application for registration of an external confiscation order under section 28(1) may be ex parte.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Evidence in support of application under section 28(1) (O. 115A, r. 5)
section.leadIn: An application for registration of an external confiscation order must be supported by an affidavit—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exhibiting the order or a verified or certified or otherwise duly authenticated copy thereof and, where the order is not in the English language, a translation thereof into English certified by a notary public or authenticated by affidavit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: stating—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the order is in force and is not subject to appeal;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, the order was made did not appear in the proceedings, that he received notice of the proceedings, in accordance with the law of the place outside Hong Kong concerned, in sufficient time to enable him to defend them;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of money, either that at the date of the application the sum payable under the order has not been paid or the amount which remains unpaid, as may be appropriate, or, in the case of other property, the property which has not been recovered; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: to the best of the deponent’s knowledge, particulars of what property the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, the order was made holds in, or controls from, Hong Kong, giving the source of the deponent’s knowledge.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Register of orders (O. 115A, r. 6)

subsection.content: The Registrar shall keep a register of the orders registered under the Ordinance.

There shall be included in such register particulars of any variation or setting aside of a registration, of any variation, satisfaction or discharge of a registered order, and of any execution issued on such an order.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Notice of registration (O. 115A, r. 7)

subsection.content: Notice of the registration of an order must be served on the person against whom, or in relation to whose property, it was obtained by delivering it to him personally or by sending it to him at his usual or last known address or place of business or in such other manner as the Court may direct.
Service of such a notice out of the jurisdiction is permissible without leave, and Order 11, rules 5, 6 and 8 shall apply in relation to such a notice as they apply in relation to a writ.
The notice shall state the period within which an application may be made to vary or set aside the registration and that the order will not be enforced until after the expiration of that period.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Application to vary or set aside registration (O. 115A, r. 8)
section.content: An application by the person against whom an order was made to vary or set aside the registration of an order must be made to a judge by summons supported by affidavit.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Enforcement of order (O. 115A, r. 9)

subsection.content: An order registered under the Ordinance shall not be enforced until after the expiration of the period specified in accordance with rule 7(3) or, if that period has been extended by the Court, until after the expiration of the period so extended.
If an application is made under rule 8, an order shall not be enforced until after such application is determined.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Variation, satisfaction and discharge of registered order (O. 115A, r. 10)
section.content: Upon the Court being notified by the applicant for registration that an order which has been registered has been varied, satisfied or discharged, particulars of the variation, satisfaction or discharge, as the case may be, shall be entered in the register.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Rules to have effect subject to orders (O. 115A, r. 11)
section.content: Rules 3 to 10 shall have effect subject to the provisions of any order made under section 27.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Investigation or proceeding relating to criminal matter—discharge and variation of orders (O. 115A, r. 12)

subsection.content: An authorized officer shall make an application for an order under section 15 ex parte to a judge by laying an information on oath.

Where an order under section 15 has been made, the person required to comply with it may apply in writing to the appropriate officer of the Court for the order to be discharged or varied, and on hearing such an application the Court may discharge the order or make such variations to it as it thinks fit.

Subject to paragraph (4), where a person proposes to make an application under paragraph (2) for the discharge or variation of an order, he shall give a copy of the application, not later than 48 hours before the making of the application, to the authorized officer by whom the application for an order was made, or if such officer is not known or cannot be found, to another authorized officer, together with a notice indicating the time and place at which the application for discharge or variation is to be made.

The Court may direct that paragraph (3) need not be complied with if it is satisfied that the person making the application has good reason to seek a discharge or variation of the order as soon as possible and it is not practicable to comply with that paragraph.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Application for restraint order or charging order (O. 115A, r. 13)

subsection.content: An application for a restraint order under section 7 or for a charging order under section 8 (to either of which may be joined an application for the appointment of a receiver) may be made by the Secretary for Justice ex parte by originating summons. (L.N. 362 of 1997; L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: An application under section 7(4) or 8(3) shall be supported by an affidavit which shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state, where applicable, the grounds for believing that an external confiscation order may be made in the proceedings instituted or to be instituted in the place outside Hong Kong concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the best of the deponent’s ability, give particulars of the realisable property in respect of which the order is sought and specify the person or persons holding such property;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in a case to which section 6(2) applies, indicate when it is intended that proceedings should be instituted in the place outside Hong Kong concerned.

subsection.content: An originating summons under paragraph (1) shall be entitled in the matter of the defendant, naming him, and in the matter of the Ordinance, and all subsequent documents in the matter shall be so entitled. (L.N. 152 of 2008)
Unless the Court otherwise directs, an affidavit under paragraph (2) may contain statements of information or belief with the sources and grounds thereof.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Restraint order and charging order (O. 115A, r. 14)

subsection.content: A restraint order may be made subject to conditions and exceptions, including but not limited to conditions relating to the indemnifying of third parties against expenses incurred in complying with the order, and exceptions relating to reasonable living expenses and reasonable legal expenses of the defendant, but the Secretary for Justice shall not be required to give an undertaking to abide by any order as to damages sustained by the defendant as a result of the restraint order.

Unless the Court otherwise directs, a restraint order made ex parte shall have effect until a day which shall be fixed for the hearing inter partes of the application and a charging order shall be an order to show cause, imposing the charge until such day.

Where a restraint order is made the Secretary for Justice shall serve copies of the order and of the affidavit in support on the defendant and on all other named persons restrained by the order and shall notify all other persons or bodies affected by the order of its terms.

Where a charging order is made the Secretary for Justice shall, unless the Court otherwise directs, serve copies of the order and of the affidavit in support on the defendant and, where the property to which the order relates is held by another person, on that person and shall serve a copy of the order on such of the persons or bodies specified in Order 50, rule 2(1)(b) to (d) as shall be appropriate.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Discharge or variation of order (O. 115A, r. 15)

subsection.content: Any person or body on whom a restraint order or a charging order is served or who is notified of such an order may apply by summons to discharge or vary the order.

The summons and any affidavit in support shall be lodged with the Court and served on the Secretary for Justice and, where he is not the applicant, on the defendant, not less than 2 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons. (L.N. 362 of 1997)
Upon the Court being notified that proceedings have been concluded any restraint or charging order shall be discharged.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Further application by Secretary for Justice (O. 115A, r. 16)

subsection.leadIn: Where a restraint order or a charging order has been made the Secretary for Justice may apply by summons or, where the case is one of urgency, ex parte— (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to discharge or vary such order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a restraint order or a charging order in respect of other realisable property; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the appointment of a receiver.

subsection.content: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit which, where the application is for a restraint order or a charging order, shall to the best of the deponent’s ability give full particulars of the realisable property in respect of which the order is sought and specify the person or persons holding such property.

The summons and affidavit in support shall be lodged with the Court and served on the defendant and, where one has been appointed in the matter, on the receiver, not less than 2 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons.
Rule 14(3) and (4) shall apply to the service of restraint orders and charging orders respectively made under this rule on persons other than the defendant.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Realisation of property (O. 115A, r. 17)

subsection.content: An application under section 9 shall, where there have been proceedings against the defendant in the Court of First Instance, be made by the Secretary for Justice by summons and shall otherwise be made by originating summons. (L.N. 362 of 1997; 25 of 1998 s. 2; L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: The summons or originating summons, as the case may be, shall be served with the evidence in support not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons on— (L.N. 152 of 2008)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person holding any interest in the realisable property to which the application relates; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the receiver, where one has been appointed in the matter.

subsection.content: The application shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall, to the best of the deponent’s ability, give full particulars of the realisable property to which it relates and specify the person or persons holding such property.
The Court may, on an application under section 9, exercise the power conferred by section 10(1) to direct the making of payments by the receiver.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Receivers (O. 115A, r. 18)

subsection.content: Subject to this rule, the provisions of Order 30, rules 2 to 8 shall apply where a receiver is appointed in pursuance of a charging order or under section 7 or 9.

Where the receiver proposed to be appointed has been appointed receiver in other proceedings under the Ordinance, it shall not be necessary for an affidavit of fitness to be sworn or for the receiver to give security, unless the Court otherwise orders.

Where a receiver has fully paid the amount payable under the external confiscation order and any sums remain in his hands, he shall apply by case management summons as to the distribution of such sums. (L.N. 152 of 2008)

subsection.leadIn: A summons under paragraph (3) shall be served with any evidence in support not less than 7 days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the defendant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person who held property realised by the receiver.

section.name: s116
section.heading: Organized and Serious Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 455)

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 116, r. 1)

subsection.content: In this Order the Ordinance (條例) means the Organized and Serious Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 455), and a section referred to by number means the section so numbered in the Ordinance.
Expressions used in this Order which are used in the Ordinance have the same meanings in this Order as in the Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application of this Order (O. 116, r. 2)
section.leadIn: This Order applies to applications—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the Secretary for Justice under section 3 for an order authorizing the Secretary for Justice to require a person to furnish information or produce material;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the Secretary for Justice or an authorized officer under section 4 for an order that a person make material available; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by an authorized officer under section 5 for the issue of a search warrant.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Assignment of proceedings (O. 116, r. 3)
section.content: For the purposes of this Order, the jurisdiction of the Court under the Ordinance shall be exercised by a judge of the Court in chambers.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Applications under section 3, 4 or 5 (O. 116, r. 4)

subsection.leadIn: An application to which this Order applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be made by laying an information on oath;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, where a judge so directs, be heard at a place other than within the court premises.

subsection.content: At the hearing of an application to which this Order applies the Court may receive evidence from the applicant.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Application to be heard in camera (O. 116, r. 5)

subsection.content: An application to which this Order applies, and any other application provided for in this Order, shall be heard in camera.

The information and all other documents relating to such application shall be treated as confidential and shall, immediately on the determination of the application, be placed in a packet and sealed by order of the judge by whom the application was heard.

subsection.leadIn: The packet shall be kept in the custody of the Court in a place to which the public has no access or in such other place as the judge may authorize and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall not be opened or its contents removed except by order of a judge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall not be destroyed except pursuant to an order of the Court.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Discharge or variation of order under section 3 or 4 (O. 116, r. 6)

subsection.content: An application under section 3(17) for the discharge or variation of an order made under section 3 or under section 4(7) for the discharge or variation of an order made under section 4(2) or (6) shall be made to a judge by summons supported by affidavit.

subsection.leadIn: The summons and affidavit in support—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall set out the grounds on which the applicant relies in seeking the discharge or variation of the order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be lodged with the Court and served on the Secretary for Justice not less than 3 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the summons. (L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.content: On the hearing of the application the Court may discharge the order or make such variation as it thinks fit.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Claim of legal privilege in relation to order under section 3 or 4 (O. 116, r. 7)

subsection.leadIn: If in the course of the exercise by an authorized officer of powers conferred by an order made under section 3 a claim of legal privilege is made in respect of any information, the person making the claim shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within 3 days of making the claim, apply to the Court by summons supported by affidavit for a declaration that the information is subject to legal privilege; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not less than 3 clear days before the hearing of the application, serve a copy of the summons and affidavit on the Secretary for Justice.

subsection.leadIn: If in the course of the exercise by an authorized officer of powers conferred by an order made under section 3 or 4 a claim of legal privilege is made in respect of any material, the person making the claim shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the presence of the authorized officer, secure the material in a sealed container;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: immediately deposit the sealed container with the Court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: within 3 days of depositing the material with the Court, apply to the Court by summons supported by affidavit for a declaration that the material is subject to legal privilege; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: not less than 3 clear days before the hearing of the application, serve a copy of the summons and affidavit on the Secretary for Justice.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Claim of legal privilege in relation to search warrant issued under section 5 (O. 116, r. 8)
section.leadIn: If in the course of execution by an authorized officer of a warrant issued under section 5 a claim of legal privilege is made in respect of any material, the person making the claim shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: secure the material in a sealed container in the presence of the authorized officer and hand the sealed container to the authorized officer for safe keeping pending an application by the person under this rule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within 3 days of making the claim of legal privilege, apply to the Court by summons supported by affidavit for a declaration that the material is subject to legal privilege; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not less than 3 clear days before the hearing of the application, serve a copy of the summons and affidavit on the authorized officer and the Secretary for Justice. (L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s117
section.heading: Organized and Serious Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 455)
section.crossHeading: Part IV—Enforcement, etc. of Confiscation Orders

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation (O. 117, r. 1)

subsection.def: In this Order the Ordinance (條例) means the Organized and Serious Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 455), and a Part or section referred to by number means the Part or section so numbered in the Ordinance.

subsection.content: Expressions used in this Order which are used in the Ordinance have the same meanings in this Order as in the Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Application of this Order (O. 117, r. 2)
section.content: This Order applies to applications under Part IV.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Assignment of proceedings (O. 117, r. 3)
section.content: The jurisdiction of the Court under the Ordinance shall, for the purposes of this Order, be exercised by a judge of the Court in chambers.

section.name: s3A
section.heading: Application for confiscation order where person has died or absconded (O. 117, r. 3A)
section.content: An application for a confiscation order under section 8 where the defendant has died or absconded may be made by the Secretary for Justice by originating summons.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Application for restraint order or charging order (O. 117, r. 4)

subsection.content: An application for a restraint order under section 15 or for a charging order under section 16 (to either of which may be joined an application for the appointment of a receiver) may be made by the Secretary for Justice ex parte by summons. (L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: An application under paragraph (1) shall be supported by an affidavit, which shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: state, as the case may be, the grounds for believing that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the defendant has benefited from a specified offence; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Court of First Instance will be satisfied as specified in section 20(1A); (90 of 1995 s. 27; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: state, as the case may be—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that proceedings have been instituted against the defendant for a specified offence (giving particulars of the offence) and that they have not been concluded;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that, whether by the laying of an information or otherwise, a person is to be charged with a specified offence;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that an application for a confiscation order has been made in respect of the defendant where section 8(1)(a)(ii) or (7A) is applicable; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: that an application has been made under section 20(1A) in respect of a confiscation order made against the defendant; (90 of 1995 s. 27)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to the best of the deponent’s ability, give full particulars of the realisable property in respect of which the order is sought and specify the person or persons holding such property;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: where proceedings have not been instituted, verify that the Secretary for Justice is to have the conduct of the proposed proceedings; (L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: e
